sion to notice what she said, because I have only to speak the truth—she told me the had said that the prisoner came back in ten minutes—I knew she led me to the door—she told me no more than I knew—I have seen the man I was drinking with several times with the prisoner, but did not knew his surname—I was sitting in the long room—there were a great many people there, but not so many as there are sometimes—the room will hold sixty or seventy—I had been there from eight till ten o'clock—the prisoner came in afterwards, and went into the third box down the room, after speaking to me—she came across the room when she first came in—I was sitting opposite the door—she did not stop in the room many minutes—I have always said that she knocked me down first—I do not exactly re
member whether she said any thing when I pulled her nose, but she went out, and shifted her clothes—I said nothing to her when she came back—she said to me, "Now come out, you b——w——, I will have it out of you now"—I do not recollect whether any body said to her, "Go and change your gown"—this is the deposition which I made my mark to—(looking at it)—it was read over to me—(The witness's deposition being ready represented the prisoner to have pulled her down before the left the room, and that it was half an hour before the returned, and upon getting to the door the said something which the witness did not hear)—I do not re
member her saying any thing at the door—he struck me three blows, the first on the nose, one on the side of my nice, and one on my lip—she went out first the second time she came in—she did not come in a third time—she was turned out directly by the waiter—I went out ten minutes or a quarter of afterwards—it was not more, I think it was not less than five minutes—I did an hour not go out at the same moment with her—I know Toomey—she was not present when the blow was struck with the key, nor yet till the key was taken out of the prisoner's hand—my bonnet was off—the was standing on the first step of the door, and struck me as I was coming out—she had the key in her hand—Thomas was with me all this time—she knocked me down, struck me twice with her fist, and then a third time; and was going to strike me again, when the key was taken out of her hand—she then made the best of her way home—I went next day to get a warrant, but the Magistrate told me to go to the station-house, and get a policeman—I went to the station-house by the Magistrate's order, got the inspector to let an officer go with me, and he found the prisoner getting over the wall.

SUSAN THOMAS . I live in New Gravel-lane. On the 8th of April I was in company with the prosecutrix at the King William public-house—she sat by the side of a sailor who had been stopping with the prisoner some nights—I had seen him frequently with her—he treated the prosecutrix to some rum—the prisoner seeing that called her names not fit to mention—the prosecutrix got up in a few minutes, and went and wrung her nose as hard as she could—I tried to prevent her doing it, and fetched her up the room, away from the prisoner—the prisoner went out in about ten minutes, and returned in about ten minutes with a cotton gown on, having had a black silk one on before—the prosecutrix and I were coming up the room, and the prisoner struck her, knocked her down, and told her to come out and fight—I said she should not, for she was too drunk to fight—one of the waiters then came, and put the prisoner out—in about ten minutes Per
kins came and told me supper was ready—I said, "Very well, help me lead the prosecutrix out," which she did, and before we could get her off the second step of the door, the prisoner struck her with the key of the door, and never spoke to her—she was outside—she struck her on the nose the first blow—altogether she struck her two or three times—she never spoke at all—she struck her on the lip the second time, and I said, "Why, Mary, you have a key in your hand"—I either called her Mary or Poll—I wrenched the key out of her hand—this is the key—(looking at it)—she struck her with the ward part—I have every reason to believe she was waiting outside the door for her—she had been out of the house about ten minutes—the prosecutrix's face bled very fast indeed.

Cross-examined. Q. You have had some conversation with the prose
cutrix since? A. Yes—I have not told her what I said before the Ma
gistrate, not to my recollection—I was in the room all the time—the prosecutrix went in with me about eight o'clock—the prisoner came in between ten and eleven o'clock—I believe the first words began a little before eleven o'clock—the prisoner called her a b——cow, not a rotten cow, in my bearing—I sat close alongside of her—the prisoner was not going out of the room, and the prosecutrix following her—the did not say, when she returned in her cotton frock, that she was ready to fight her then—she stood with her back against a fruit-basket, struck her, and knocked her down—I took her up—I said nothing to the prisoner—I did not hear Pearson say, "There is no law for pulling noses or kicking * * * I was in company with Pearson from first to last—I might have left her a minute—she and the prisoner were not going out to fight—Pearson did not try to hit her after they got out of the house—the first of the scuffle was the prisoner's trying to hit her with the key—Pearson laid hold of the sleeves of her gown, that is all—the prisoner did not say in my hearing, "I don't wish to fight with keys"—when Pearson got up she was bleeding from the face—she was struck down by Mr. Talbot's window—she fell in the kennel, about the middle of that window—there is no step where she fell—she was knocked down by a blow in the face from the prisoner—she did not fall on the curb-stone, she fell in the gutter, close to the curb—she did not say, "I will make your browns come out"—they did not both fall to
gether into the kennel—the prisoner dragged her to the second house, and then knocked her down in Talbot-passage, and was repeating the blows till she was taken off by me and Perkins—I did not tell Pearson she was bleeding—I said to Perkins, "Look how her face is bleeding"—I did not hear Pearson say, "Never mind a little blood, it will not hurt me," but I

could not notice all the words, I was in a flurry—Pearson tore the sleeves of the prisoner's gown as she laid hold of them, when she fell, to prevent her falling, and both her sleeves came out—the prisoner fell on her.

HANNAH PERKINS . I live with the last witness. I went to the King William public-house between eleven and-twelve o'clock, to tell her that supper was ready—I assisted Pearson out of the house—I did not observe the prisoner till she struck Pearson, which she did with a key, and re
peated the blow—Thomas got the key from her afterwards—Pearson fell on her back afterwards with the blows the prisoner gave her—the prisoner was still beating her when I and Thomas went and took her from her.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner struck the blow without saying any thing? A. She did—it was a violent blow—Thomas took the key after the blow had been repeated twice, as far as I recollect—the prisoner then caught hold of Pearson's hair, dragged her into the second house, knocked her down in the passage, and beat her—I took her from her, and said, "Liverpool Poll, don't hit her down"—I did not see the prisoner when I went into the public-house, not till I came out with the prosecutrix—I did not see her as I went in at the door—there was a scuffling going down to Tolbot's house—they had no fight, Pearson was too much in liquor to strike at all—she did not lift her hand to the prisoner—Pearson fell twice, the first time was in the road, on her back, and the next time in the pas
sage of the house—she did not fall on the curb-stone—I did not hear her say, "Never mind a little blood, it won't hurt me"—I certainly should have heard it if she had said so—I will swear the did not say so—I did not hear it mentioned.

GEORGE HALE (police-constable K 54.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 9th—she said it was not done with a key—there were a great many girls there at the time, and they said, "Oh, you did not do it, she did it in falling"—I said, "I think it was not done in falling"—she said, "Yes, it was," that the prosecutrix was very drunk, and did it herself in falling.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you find the prisoner immediately you went after her? A. No, I did not, because they go from one house to another so—I took her in one of the houses, not the house she lived in.

JOHN WILLIAM BIRD . I am a surgeon, and live in Ratcliff-highway. The prosecutrix was brought to me on the night of Wednesday, the 8th, to have her face dressed—her nose was cut across, at least it was divided—the bridge was broken, and her lip divided in two places—they were contused wounds, not such as a person would receive by a fall in the street—there are three distinct wounds—the one across the nose is a transverse one, the other longitudinal, and the other oblique—the cut on the upper lip was oblique and fiat over, so that the force must have been applied upwards, and there is an excoriation on the nose upwards, which would not occur in a fall—it was certainly not done by falling on the ground—this key would produce such appearances—it must have been applied with considerable violence—the wounds correspond with the key, and the key is stained with blood now.

Cross-examined. Q. If a person fell against the curb-stone, might not that cut the lip, and break the teeth? A. Not in that way—such a thing is possible, but the wounds were all in different directions—I was not told what had been the matter when she was brought to me—she and the two young women came, and they were all enraged of course.

WILLIAM MARSHALL . I am a baker, and live in New Gravel-lane—MR. Talbot is my master. On the 8th of April, between ten and eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner and prosecutrix come out of the King William public-house—I was standing at my shop-door, which is next to it—they both came out—the prosecutrix first—the prisoner followed her—the pro
secutrix fell down on the curb without any body touching her—she came running up against the prisoner—there were three or four persons coming out—the prosecutrix ran up to the prisoner to make a blow at her, and fell down on the curb—I saw Thomas lift her up.

COURT. Q. Did the prosecutrix come out of the house quietly by her
self, or was she lifted along? A. She walked out alone—nobody helping her on one side or the other—I was first asked to be a witness to-day—I do not know who applied to me—I was at work, and one of the witnesses came up for me—I do not know her name—I do not know any of their names.

MARY ANN TOOMEY . I am single, and live in New Gravel-lane. Last Wednesday night, between ten and eleven o'clock, I was in the long room at the King William public-house—I use the house as an unfortunate girl—the prosecutrix was there—the prisoner came in afterwards, came down the room, and spoke to me and another woman—she was standing speak
ing to me, and the prosecutrix came down and said "B—Cumberland Poll, there is no law for pinching noses or kicking" * * *, and pulled her nose—that was before any thing was said to her—the prisoner said nothing to her—the waiter came up and said he would not have a row there, and the prisoner went outside the door—the prosecutrix followed her out, and going out, pulled her cap and beads off, gave them to Thomas, and as she got out at the door, she said, "You b—Cumberland Poll, now I will give you what you have wanted for a long time," with that she was going to hit the prisoner, and Thomas said, "Don't strike, she has got a key in her hand"—the prisoner said, "I don't want to hit with the key, you can take the key," and gave it to her out of her bosom—she then struck her, and both fell down on the curb—they were both the worse for liquor—Thoomas said, "Your face is bloody"—she said, "Never mind a little blood, it will do me no harm"—they fell to fighting again, and fell into Mr. Talbot's passage, and when she got up she was all over blood.

COURT. Q. When the prosecutrix called her these bad names nobody struck then? A. No—the prosecutrix wrung her nose twice, and she said, "Don't tear my things"—she was dressed very nicely—when she came out the prosecutrix followed her to fight her—the prisoner went out of the house first, and the prosecutrix came out presently after—they were both the worse for liquor—the prisoner did not change her gown—she had a very nice dark silk gown on—she did not go away for a short time, and then return, to my knowledge—she had the same dress on when she was rolling on the ground, as she had before.

MR. HORRY. Q. Did you see the prosecutrix taken away? A. Yes, by Thomas, and her servant—the prisoner had gone home then—I did not hear her call Pearson a b—rotten cow—I should have heard it if she had—I never heard her say any bad words to her, she only told her not to tear her things.

MARY ANN BRADEN . I am single, and live in New Grayel-lane. I was in the King William public-house, and saw the prisoner and prosecu
trix

there—the prisoner came down the room—the prosecutrix followed her, and said, "There is no law for pinching noses or kicking * * *"—the prisoner said, "Don't tear my clothes"—I took her bonnet, and she walked out of the long room—the prosecutrix left her beads and cap at the bar, followed her oat, and said, "Now, b—Cumberland Poll, I am ready for you;" with that, Thomas said, "Poll, don't fight with no keys"—the prisoner said, "I don't want to fight with keys, here is the key," and she gave it very freely up to Thomas—Thomas did not wrench it out of her hand—she did not use it—the prosecutrix then made a strike at the prisoner—the prisoner said she did not want to fight—she merely shoved the prosecutrix, and she fell on the ground—she got up, and Thomas said, "You are bleeding"—she said, "A little blood won't hurt me, come on, b—Poll, I am not afraid of you," with that she fell against my door, and that cut her.

COURT. Q. Did you see the waiter take her out? A. The waiter said, "Go out, don't fight in my room"—there was not an interval of ten minutes between her being taken out, and being found outside—the pri
soner had a light frock on when she had the key, but when she first came in she had a black silk dress on—she was told to go home and change her dress, that the prosecutrix might not hurt her things—she only slipped on her light dress, and came back again, and the prosecutrix insulted her again—Thomas took the prisoner's apron off, and tore the sleeves off her gown, and said, "This will do for the b—to-morrow"—the prosecutrix said she would make the b—sport her browns"—Thomas wiped the blood off the prosecutrix's face with the prisoner's apron—the prosecutrix said, "Never mind a little blood," and then she said she was ready for her again.

MARY ANN MOTT . I am married. I went to the King William pub
lic-house to get my husband's supper beer—the prisoner came out at the door, and talked to two females—after that I saw Pearson without a cap—she said, "B——Cumberland Poll, I am ready for you"—Thomas asked the prisoner for the key, and she gave it to her—I did not see her doing any thing with it—Thomas said, "Now I have got the key, we will make it up with browns to-morrow"—I then saw the prosecutrix run towards the prisoner to bit her, but she was so drunk she fell down and cut her lip—she got up—Perkins said, "Mary Ann, your mouth is bleeding"—she said, "I don't mind a little blood"—she went to strike the prisoner again, but fell against Mr. Talbot's door, and fell down backwards.
COURT. Q. Did you see how she cut her lip? A. Yes, by the curb, and she split her nose up against the door—I only saw the prisoner in one dress—that was a lightish one.
MR. HORRY. Q. Do you know Talbot's door? A. Yes—it has a sharp edge—I saw it next morning, and there is all the blood on it now—as soon as the blow was struck it spirted out.

MARIA WHITE . I am an unfortunate girl, and live in New-court, New Gravel-lane. I was at the King William public-house—the prosecutrix was there—the prisoner came down the long-room—the prosecutrix fol
lowed her and said, "Now, b——Cumberland Poll, there is no law for wringing noses or kicking * * *"—she did wring her nose, and she lifted her foot to kick her, but I could not swear whether she did or not—I left the room for about ten minutes, then went down the lane, and saw the pro
secutrix, Thomas, and Perkins, together, all on the prisoner—Thomas
pulled the apron off the prisoner's side, and took it to wipe the prosecutrix's face with—Thomas said, "That will do, b——Cumberland Poll, I will make you sport your browns for this to-morrow."

CHARLOTTE ANDREWS . I am single and live in New Gravel-lane. I was at the King William public-house last Wednesday night, and saw the prosecutrix there—the prisoner came in very nicely dressed, and went down the long-room—the prosecutrix followed her and said, "I owe it you"—the prisoner said, "What for?"—she said, "There is no law for pulling noses or kicking * * *," and pulled her nose twice—the waiter said, "Don't fight here, if you want to fight go out"—with that the prisoner went out, the prosecutrix pulled off her cap and beads, left them at the bar, and followed her and said, "Now, b——Poll, if you want any thing, I will give it you"—Thomas said, "Don't fight with that key"—she said, "I don't want to fight with the key," and gave it to Thomas—the prosecutrix said, "Now, come on, we will have it"—the prisoner said, "I don't want to fight you"—she pushed her, and she fell in the gutter, and her face went on the curb—she got up, and Thomas said, "Your face bleeds"—she said, "Never mind; I don't mind a little blood"—she was going to fight again, and the prisoner and her fell down in the passage—her nose bled, and Thomas took off the prisoner's apron and wiped her nose with it—somebody said it was the prisoner's apron—she said, "Never mind that, that will do; for I will make her pull out her browns to-morrow."

COURT. Q. How was the prisoner dressed outside the public-house? A. She had a brown silk dress, a crape shawl, and a Tuscan bonnet—she said to the prosecutrix, "Don't tear my things," and she went home and shifted herself—it was at the second insult that the prosecutrix followed her out—she came in again after changing her dress, and went down to have something to drink with a young man, and the prosecutrix said, "If you want any thing, I can give it to you."

GUILTY.—Of an Assault.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1234.
STEPHEN FOWLER was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Kingsmill, on the 1st of April, and stealing 9 shillings, the monies of
Dennis Toomey.

DENNIS TOOMEY . I live at the house of Mary Kingsmill, in Ball-yard, Belton-street, St. Giles's. I have known the prisoner some time—he was in the habit of coming backwards and forwards to the house. On Wednes
day morning the 1st of April, I had 9s. in a box in my room—I locked the box and put the key into my pocket—I laid the box on a table by the kitchen door—it could be seen from the street through the window—I locked the kitchen door safely, and brought the key away—about six o'clock that evening, on returning home, I found the kitchen door burst open—the hasp was pulled out—my box was on the table broken open, and the money gone—I went in search of the prisoner, and found him in the kitchen when I returned—I charged him with robbing me—he said he had robbed me, and spent part of the money, and he would give me his clothes next morning to pawn to make it up—I gave him in charge, but he was dis
charged before the Magistrate, as I had not the witness I have now, and I did not think of telling the Magistrate what the prisoner had said to me.
Cross-examined by MR. LUCAS. Q. Why did you charge him? A. I accused him of it because a boy had told me it was him—this was a few

days after the robbery—he was discharged on Thursday, taken again on Sunday, and before the Magistrate on Monday—I get my living by labour
ing work, and when I cannot get work I carry things in Covent Garden
market—I get 18s. a week—I was a good many weeks putting that 9s. by—I am married, and have children—my wife does a little—she washed for the prisoner once, but not for two months before the robbery, because the last washing he did not pay her for.

RICHARD BARTON . I am twelve years old, and live with my father in the same house as the prosecutor—the prisoner formerly lived in the same street—I have often seen him. On the evening of the 1st of April, a little before six o'clock I went into the yard and saw the prisoner come through the passage—he went down the kitchen stairs, pulled the hasp out of the door, went in, got the poker, and broke open the box—I ran down the area, looked through the window, and saw him take the money out of the box and put it into his pocket—he came out and went into Broad-street—I told the prosecutor, and he went in search of him—I am quite sure he is the person.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. A good long while—I know him perfectly—I was at the top of the kitchen stain when I saw him do this—the kitchen stairs lead into the yard—the street door is not left open, but on the latch—any body could open it—I knew where the box was because I used to go into the room—I always saw the box there—it was locked—I did not know there was money in it—I could see it was silver money he took—there ware no halfpence—it was 9s.—Dennis told me so—the prisoner took it out with his hand—he broke the box open with a poker—it was a good large box, about two feet by one—he knocked the front piece of wood out—I watched him because I saw him making a row at the kitchen door polling out the hasp—the kitchen door is at the foot of the stairs directly opposite it—I was on the kitchen stairs when I saw him take up the poker—I then ran round, looked down the area, and saw him break the box open—I could see down to the door from the stairs—I did not tell Toomey what evidence I was going to give to-day—I have had no quarrel with the prisoner.

JOHN BLOOMFIELD (police-constable E 143.) I went with Barton for him to point out where be stood when he saw the kitchen door broken open—it is on the landing at the head of the stain—I could see the kitchen door from that place—he afterwards took me outside to look down the area—a person there could see the box on the table, and all that passed in the kitchen.

Cross-examined. Q. Does the kitchen open straight from the top of the staircase? A. Yes—the window is about a yard on the right on the side facing the door—I could just see the edge of the window from the stair
case—the box was on the table in front of the door, not a yard from the window—I could see the table when the door was open—it stood between the door and window—the boy described every thing to me—when Too
mey gave the prisoner in charge he mentioned what the prisoner had done, but did not state about his confession the first time.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Months.

1235.
HENRY BLEASE was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of March, 3 pairs of boots, value 5s., the goods of
Catherine Scanlan.

CATHERINE SCANLAN . I am a widow, and keep a clothes shop in Austin-street, Bethnal-green. On the 20th of March I hung some boots out for sale—six or seven hours after I saw the prisoner in custody of Kemp, with three pairs of boots, which I had seen safe about half-an-hour before.

Cross-examined by Mr. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure about their being yours? A. Yes—I had had them tome days—these are them—(looking at them)—I know them by particular marks—they hung by a rope on a nail at the upper side of the door-post.

GEORGE KEMP (police-constable N 82.) On the 20th of March I was on duty in Old street-road a little before six o'clock in the evening, and I saw the prisoner and his companion in company larking together—I watched them for half-an-hour—I saw them go up to the prosecutrix's shop, look at some shoes at the door, and pass by—the prisoner then sat down on the next door step—his companion passed by the step several times, and each time came and talked to the prisoner—the prisoner got up, and looked into the window—his companion then took the shoes down, and both ran off together—I pursued and took the prisoner—his companion dropped the shoes—the prisoner said he saw the other take the shoes, and he ran after him to stop him—they had both run away together—I fol
lowed them better than a quarter of a mile—they both ran off at one time and in the same direction—the boots were dropped in a street a quarter of a mile from the prosecutrix's—the prisoner was running in the same direc
tion as the other, but he never called "Stop thief" or any thing till I stop
ped him—the other passed the prisoner in running, and the prisoner joined, and both ran together—the other was about ten or twelve yards beyond the prisoner when I took him.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not cry "Stop thief," did you? A. Yes, and ran as hard as I could—I was on the opposite side of the way, forty or fifty yards off—I got into a very bad place, and was surrounded by thieves.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1236.
SARAH WHITE was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 1/2lb. weight of ham, value 1s., the goods of
George Morgan, and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Six Months.

1237.
MARY ANN FROUD was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 pair of boots, value 4s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
John Mortlock; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined One Month.

1238.
JOHN HANNON was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of April, 1 box, value 12s., the goods of
William Howard.

WILLIAM HOWARD . I live in Great Russell-street. I lost a box, on the 16th of April, from outside my door—this is it (looking at one)—I saw the prisoner running from a door-way, and ran and secured him—I did not see him with the box.

HENRY FARDO . I live in Great Russell-street. I saw the prisoner take the box from the prosecutor's door—I am sure he it the man—he took it to No. 17, Great Russell-street, when he saw me and Mr. Howard running out, he put it down and ran away.
Prisoner. Q. You did not see me take it. Witness. Yes, I am sure you are the man.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

1239.
SOPHIA WALLIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of July, 1 carpet, value 10s.; 6 blankets, value 30s.; 4 decanters, value 1l.; 2 water-bottles, value 3s.; 6 goblets, value 9s.; and 2 salt-cellars, value 2s.; the goods of
John Hercy, her master.

THOMAS TELLING . I am butler to Mr. John Hercy, of Baker-street. On the 1st of July he and his family left town, leaving the prisoner in charge of the house—they returned on the 4th of March, and then I missed the things stated, which were left at home in her care—these are them—(examining them.)

WILLIAM JONES . I have two blankets, which were pledged by the pri
soner or her daughter, I do not know which.

JAMES REARDON . I live with Mr. Ross, a pawnbroker in East-street. This carpet was taken in by a young man who has left the employ, in the name of Jane Watson—here are some blankets and other things, all taken in by the same person.

JONATHAN POLLARD (police-constable D 125.) I went to the prose
cutor's house on the 12th of March, and saw the prisoner—I found forty
nine duplicates, amongst which were those of this property in her room in Baker-court—no one else lodged there.
(The prisoner received a good character, and pleaded poverty.)

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Six Months.

1240.
RICHARD KIPLING was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of March, 16 pieces of crystal, value 18s., the goods of
George Pilkington, his master.

GEORGE PILKINGTON . I am an optician, living in Clarence-place, Pentonville. The prisoner was my errand-boy—I lost sixteen pieces of crystal, called Bristol pebbles, on the 13th of March—they were safe on the 12th—these are them—(looking at them.)
JOSEPH SMITH . The prisoner brought these to me on the 13th of March. I knew a dog that he had with him to be the prosecutor's, and detained him.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1241.
JAMES HAYLEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
James Browne, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Eight Days.

1242.
WILLIAM SHERMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of January, 11 writing-desks, value 4l. 10s. 8s., the goods of
George Henry Burgess.

GEORGE HENRY BURGESS . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Bath-street, Leonard-square. On the 16th of January the prisoner applied to me for twelve writing-desks—I had but eleven—he said they would do—he asked me to sell them to him—I asked if he could pay for them—he said, "No"

—he asked if I had a servant that could go with him to a customer he had got for them—I said I would allow my servant to take them to the house, and bring the money to me, and his profit was to be allowed out of the money—my servant went, and came home drunk without the money or the desks—they have not been found.

JAMES ATKINS . I went with the desks—I was to carry them to the place the prisoner had to sell them to, and receive 4l. 10s. 8d. for the eleven desks—we went from shop to shop and did not sell one, till it came rather late in the evening, and having many pots of beer, which he paid for, I got a little too much, and all I can recollect at last was, we went to a house to leave the desks, he took me to a lodging-house to sleep, and said he would take me to some more shops to sell them—he then said he was going backwards—he did not pay the money for the lodging—the landlady said so—I went next day, and could get no intelli
gence of the desks—I carried part of them to the house—they were too heavy for one to carry—I never received the money.

HENRY HAMILTON . I am shopman to Charles Daniels. About ten o'clock at night, on the 16th of January, the prisoner came with Atkins, and offered some desks for sale—we said we did not want any—he asked to leave them till morning—I said I did not mind, and in the morning the prisoner came by himself and took them away.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1243.
WILLIAM JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of April, 31bs. weight of mutton, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
William Pain.

WILLIAM PAIN . I am a butcher, living I Cleveland-street, Mary-le
bone. On the 7th of April the prisoner came to my shop, and I saw him take a breast of mutton—I hallooed at him—he went off, and threw it into a green-grocer's shop next door—this is it.
(The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to take care of him.)

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Eight Days, and
Whipped.

1244.
THOMAS WAKEFIELD was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Matthews and another; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

WILLIAM GOFTON . I am shopman to John Matthews and another, who are pawnbrokers. On the 4th of March I saw the prisoner take a pair of boots from inside the shop—he ran down a court—I pursued, calling "Stop thief," and the policeman took him—I did not find the boots on him—these are them—(examining them.)
JOHN RUSSELL (police-constable G 165.) I saw the prisoner drop the boots at the corner of White Bear-yard—I took him.
JOHN BULLOCK (police-constable G 116.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1245.
HARRIET HAMMOND was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 1 printed book, value 8s., the goods of
Mary Ann Jennings.

MARY ANN JENNINGS . I live in Brompton-terrace, Kensington—the prisoner lodged with me. I missed this Watts's hymn-book about ten days after she left, which was on the 4th of January—I did not lend it to her.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANS. Q. Do you let lodgings? A. Yes—I had other lodgers—I had no objection to let my lodgers read a reli
gious book—I generally kept it on the kitchen shelf.
JOHN GOULD . I am the prisoner's landlord. When the broker took an inventory of her things for me, I found this book in her box.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had she been in your house? A. About ten weeks—I put in a distress for rent—I saw the name of Mrs. Jennings in the book, and went to her—she did not go to the police-office till I took the prisoner up myself.

THOMAS TRINGHAM (police-sergeant B 18.) I asked the prisoner about the book—she said it had been lent to her by Mrs. Jennings, and she did not return it, as Mrs. Jennings was such a reprobate, she was not fit to read a religious book.
NOT GUILTY .

1246.
HARRIET HAMMOND was again indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 2 knives, value 1s., the goods of
John Gould.
MARTHA GOULD . I was at my father's house on the Monday afternoon, when the prisoner's box was searched—I saw these two knives found—I know them by the maker's name on them.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you find in her box other knives of her own? A. Yes—they were larger, but had white handles like these.
JOHN GOULD . I lost a good many things—these knives are mine.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner lodged with you? A. Yes—I gave her notice—she could not pay her rent, and I put in a distress—I exa
mined her box before the broker—I charged her with stealing my daugh
ter's bonnet—the inspector dismissed that charge—I charged her with stealing three towels, and the Magistrate dismissed that.
NOT GUILTY .

1247.
JOHN LITTLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 71bs. weight of coffee, value 12s. 6d., the goods of
William Overall.

WILLIAM OVERALL . I am a grocer, and live in Green-street, Leicester-squar About a quarter before four o'clock on the 8th of April, the pri
oner came into my shop and took this bag of coffee from the box it laid on—he ran out with it—I ran, and overtook him—I never lost sight of him—I saw him throw the coffee into an area—this is my coffee.
GEORGE ANDERSON (police-constable C 85.) I took the prisoner, and got the coffee out of an area where the prisoner had thrown it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming out of Green-court, and heard the cry of "Stop thief"—a young man had just passed me—I was following him, and three gentlemen stopped me—it was nearly a minute and a half before this man came up—I know no more about it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for seven Years.

1248.
JAMES CHAPMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of April, 1 basket, value 9d.; and 14lbs. weight of potatoes, value 9d.; the goods of
James Bowry.

JAMES BOWRY . I live in Ray-street, Clerkenwell. About half-past ten o'clock on the evening of the 6th of April I missed a basket of pota
toes—I ran to the door, and saw the prisoner with them, and lodging them on a pair of steps leading up to some houses—I took him with them—they were inside my shop.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man—we had a pint or two of ale; he left me, and said he would meet me at the Britannia; I have no recol
lection of any thing more.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

1249.
JAMES HAZELL and
JOHN GASPAR were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 11th of March, 1 jacket, value 25s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 20s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 hat, value 2s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 pair of boots, value 7s.; 3 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the property of
Thomas Bell.

THOMAS BELL . I am a sailor, belonging to the Queen Victoria, of Aberdeen, On the 11th of March I came to London—about ten or eleven o'clock I met some person whom I do not know, they called him Jack—he introduced me to a lodging-house where he was himself—the two pri
soners were there—they told me to go to bed, and I should be safe in the morning—I did so, and about an hour after Gaspar came and looked over me in the bed—Hazell was behind him, and took my boots—I did not halloo out to them, as I thought it was no harm—I had put my things under my head, that they might be safe in the morning, as Gaspar told me—I had tied the door, as Gaspar told me, but they had cut the string—I got up in the morning, and all my things were gone, and the prisoners too—I do not know who took any thing but the boots.

Gaspar. Q. When I met you did I stop you and take you to a place? A. Yes—we went to one public-house, and then to another—I had 5s. or 6s.—I had 3s. 6d. when I went to bed—I paid you 1s. for my supper, and gave you a share of two pots of beer—all that was left in the morning was my keys—a servant of the house took me to bed—you forbid me to give my things to the mistress, but told me to put them under my head, and they would be safe—you came up without a light—I saw you open the door—it was light enough to see you—there was a sky-light above where I lay—it was moon-light—I saw you take the boots—I did not speak to you, because you pretended to be a friend.

MART ANN SIEX . I lodge at this house. I remember Gaspar came home with the prosecutor—Hazell was in the house at the time—I heard them talk together most of the evening, they said it would be a pity for any one to meddle with his clothes, and they would take care no one should—they drank together—the prosecutor wanted some supper, and the prisoners fetched a loaf and some sausages—the prosecutor gave them the money—about two o'clock Hazell came into my room, and took off his shoes, and left them by my bed-side—I do not know whether he put on the boots—he went to Sal's bed-side, and said to her, "Get up, we are going to nail the sailor"—she said she would have nothing to do with it—about six o'clock in the morning the prosecutor came into my room, and asked me where the man was that brought him there—I said he slept in the next room, and the prisoners were gone, they had not come to bed at all that night.
Gaspar. Q. How long was I in the house? A. Five or six weeks—the prosecutor was only there one night.

EMMA BROWN . I lodge at this house. I was sleeping in the adjoining bed to Gaspar—he went to his wife, and told her he was going to rob the sailor—he went out again, and came in again, and said the sailor should
only have 2s.—he undressed himself, and went out again, he came in again, and said he should dress himself in the sailor's clothes, and should be in the coffee-shop till the morning.

Gaspar. Q. Do you mean to say you saw me come into the room? A. Yes—I went to bed about half-an-hour before the sailor—you said to your wife, "I am going to rob the sailor," and she began to cry, and said, "His but and shoes are under the bed"—I cannot tell what you did with your clothes—your wife went to bed after me—I do not know whether it was morning—I saw you go out of the room without your clothes.

Gaspar's Defence. I had lodged there seven or eight weeks; Hazell had only been there one night—I met the prosecutor, who asked where he could get a lodging. I took him to where I lodged; we had our supper, and I said to him, "If you will take my advice, put your clothes under your head, as we always do;" he was taken to bed by the servant-girl, who has run away since; there was no light in the room, and he could not see me; he never said one word when he saw this man take his boots; Brown is not to be believed—she says she heard me say I was going to rob the sailor, and why did she not tell the man by the side of her to go and tell the sailor? She said she would get me transported.

Hazell's Defence. I know nothing about it; I wished to go to bed be
fore this prisoner and the sailor came home, but they said they had no candlestick; my shoes were under the bed before the sailor came home.

HAZELL—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

GASPAR—
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years.

1250.
MARY FARRELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of March, 1 1/2 yard of printed cotton, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
George Clarke; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE CLARKE . I keep a linen-draper's shop in Whitecross-street, St. Luke's. On the Friday after the 16th of March Hayward called to know if I had lost any thing—I had seen the prisoner in my shop on the 16th—I did not miss 'any thing till Hayward came—I saw this printed cotton safe in my shop on Monday morning, the 16th—I had not sold it—I have missed it—it is mine, and has my private mark on it—it was a rem
nant, and could not be sold without asking me, as the price was not marked.

HARRIET HATWARD . I am a searcher at the station-house—I was sent for to search the prisoner on Monday evening, the 16th of March—she said she had not a farthing's worth about her, but in her basket I found this print.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought it for 1s. 4d. in his shop; I have a wit
ness to prove it.
THOMAS COTTEE (police-constable E 205.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1251.
ANN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 28 yards of printed cotton, value 10s., the goods of
John Dent.

GEORGE BUCKELL . I am shopman to John Dent, a linen-draper, in Crawford-street. About eight o'clock, on the 27th of March, I was pass
ing

inside my shop, and saw the prisoner at the door, looking at some fur
niture on a board inside the shop—I had suspicion, and looked round a pile of carpet, saw her take a piece, put it under her cloak, and walk off with it—I stopped her at the corner of Union-place, opened her cloak, and saw it in her hand—I brought her back, and she dropped it in the door
way.
DANIEL GRIMWOOD (police-sergeant D 11.) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was looking at it; he came, and said I meant to steal it; I had not got from the door.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

1252.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for breaking and entering the shop of
Henry Isaac Mayes, at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green, and steal
ing therein 20 pieces of woollen cloth, value 2s., his goods.

HENRY ISAAC MAYES . I am a tailor, and live in Portugal-place, Cam
bridge-road, St. Matthew, Bethnal-green. I was walking past my shop about nine o'clock, on the 6th of April—I saw the door broken, one man inside the shop, and the other out—the prisoner was one—I said, "Halloo!"—they said, "It is all right"—I said, "I don't think it is all right"—I sung out, "Police," and "Stop thief"—the two men made a rush to get out—there is a sort of wicket-gate, and the other man's hat fell off, and in it was a number of these pieces of woollen cloth he got from me—I ran after him to Northampton-street, and lost sight of him for five or six minutes—I then went back to the shop, knowing I had left it just as the men ran out—then I found the hat outside the gateway, and also a bundle, containing the remainder of the pieces, wrapped up in a silk handkerchief—the prisoner was one of the two men I saw there—I have no doubt, I am sure of him—I cannot say whether he was outside or inside the door—I had left the door safely shut up.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you not at first express some doubt about his being the man? A. When he was brought to me, he turned and said, "Then you swear I am the person"—I said, "Stop till we get to the shop, because I should not like to say I know you are the man till I am positive"—it was about nine o'clock at night—the pieces of cloth are worth 2s.—nothing was found on him.

HENRY LEWIS TYTLAR . I am a tailor, and live in Whitechapel-road. I was in Cambridge-road on that evening—I saw the prisoner running up Northampton-street to Essex-street, and then he got over a garden-wall—he said, "Let me be, I will not run"—I had made no charge against him then—he did not say it to any one in particular, but there were several peo
ple standing round—he then walked a few yards, and began to run—the had left policeman who came up pursued and took him.

Cross-examined. Q. There were a number of people collected? A. Yes—this garden is about ten feet long—he had just come over the garden-wall when he said, "Let me alone"—I was coming along the road, and heard the cry of "Stop thief"—there might be twenty people.

DANIEL HEGARTY (police-constable K 201.) I heard the cry of "Stop thief," and came up with this man, in possession of two men—he was pointed out as the person who attempted to commit the robbery—I took him to the prosecutor, who gave him in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner denied it? A. Yes.

GUILTY .* Aged 30.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1253.
JOHN CARROLL and
JAMES ROACH were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April, 2 pump-boxes, value 10s., the goods of
Tho
mas Heath and another.

JOHN ROSS . I am chief mate of the ship Malcolm, belonging to Tho
mas Heath. These pump-boxes, belonging to the ship, were in the car
penter's store-room, and on the 2nd of April I had them moved, about the middle of the day—they were loose—on the morning of the 3rd I was called to the station-house, and missed them out of the ship—I believe them to belong to Thomas Heath and another, as far as the ship is con
cerned.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Who is the other partner? A. Captain James Froome; and I believe there are other partners besides him, but I do not know who they are.
EDWARD POYNTON . I am night watchman. I stopped the prisoners with the property—I do not know who owns the ship.
NOT GUILTY .

1254.
HENRY HORNER, alias Cooper,
was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 12 pain of socks, value 11s., the goods of
William Boome.

GEORGE LAWS . I am a shopman to William Broome, a hosier, in Ox
ford-street. About eight o'clock in the evening, of the 30th of March I saw these socks safe just inside the door—I saw them unusually working up and down—I ran to the door, and saw the prisoner with another lad run off—I followed, and saw the prisoner throw these socks up Marylebone-lane—I followed, and took him—they are called half-hose in the trade—some people call them socks.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Where were you? A. Behind the counter serving a customer—I was three yards in the shop—I had to come five or six yards round to the door—I gave an alarm to a young man; and went round myself—a person outside might see me in the shop—it was about eight o'clock at night—I saw the prisoner and another lad running from the door—I saw the string was cut—I found they were gone before I ran out—I never said I ran out, and found the parcel gone—I could not miss them till I got to the door—the prisoner was about three yards from the door when I went out—I turned to see the parcel was cut, and they ran off directly—before I came out I saw the parcel was missing—the per
sons I saw were to the left—I pursued the prisoner, and he threw them from his hand up Marylebone-lane, which is three or four yards from the shop—I saw them while I was standing at the door—when I got out they were walking—I followed the prisoner to Welbeck-street, about a hundred yards—I did not lose sight of him—I was not more than two or three yards behind him—I slipped for a minute, or I should have caught him long before.

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1255.
CHARLOTTE EVANS and
FRANCES GREEN were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 28th of March, 1 quilt, value 4s.; 2 blankets, value 8s.; 1 tea-kettle, value 3s.; 1 sheet, value 5s.; and 1 pillow-case, value 1s.; the goods of
Susannah Lane.
SUSANNAH LANE . I am a widow, living in Mary-street, Hampstead-road. On the 28th of March Evans took a furnished lodging at my house
as a married woman, but when she came she brought Green as her sister—I have lost the articles stated—these are them—(looking at them.)

JOHN WELLS . I am a pawnbroker, living in Adam's-row, Hampstead-road. This tea-kettle I took in of Evans, and the blankets and sheets were taken in of Green, on the 28th of March, by my young man in my presence.
Evans's Defence. I did it through distress.

EVANS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

GREEN—
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against Evans.)

1256.
MARGARET MILLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of March, 3 blankets, value 15s.; 2 sheets, value 5s.; 2 pillows, value 5s.; 2 candlesticks, value 3s.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s.; 2 towels, value 2s.; and 1 carpet, value 1l.; the goods of
Samuel Hobbins.

JANE HOBBINS . I am the wife of Samuel Hobbins, a painter, and live in Bouverie-street, Edgeware-road. The prisoner took my ready furnished lodging, and I missed the articles stated—these are them—(looking at them.)

DAVID HUNN . I am in the employ of Mr. Button, a pawnbroker, in John-street, Edgeware-road. On the 7th of March the prisoner pledged one of the blankets, and another one on the 19th—a sheet and candlestick, a table-cloth, two towels, and other things on the 21st.

GUILTY. Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

1256.
JOHN CROFT and
MARY CROFT were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of March, 1 copper-lid, value 2s., the goods, of
James Ni
cholson.

JAMES NICHOLSON . I keep the sutling-house at St. James's-palace. On the 27th of March the prisoners came to my house together, about four o'clock in the afternoon—the man asked for half-a-pint of beer—they went into the tap-room, and sat together—I had seen this copper-lid safe that day between eleven and twelve o'clock—I had occasion to send the boy out while they were in the tap-room, and while he was away the man came to the bar, and called for half-a-pint of beer—while I was serving, the woman passed me, and I saw the copper-lid projecting from under her cloak—the man stepped inside the tap-room, and then he followed her.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were there any people in the tap-room? A. Not that tap-room—there was in another—I have not found the copper-lid.

COURT. Q. Why did you not stop her? A. It is a usual thing for mechanics to come and eat their dinners at my house, and I thought it might be her property—all I know is I saw something like a copper-lid under her cloak.
HENRY GALLIMORE . On the 27th of March I left the copper-lid safe a little after four o'clock—I came back in about five minutes, and then the party and the lid were gone.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there oyster people and other people in the tap-room? A. Yes—there were no soldiers in the other tap-room.
NOT GUILTY .

1258.
WILLIAM DEMMETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of March, 10 loaves of bread, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
Richard Hooke, his master.

RICHARD HOOKE . I am a baker, and live in Shoe-lane—the prisoner was my servant—on the 13th of March I sent him, among other places, to Mrs. Norie, in Bear-alley, with fifteen loaves—he brought word back that they wanted ten more, and in the afternoon I sent him with ten more—he came to the counter and had them booked—here is the book in which they are entered—on the Monday morning he was to take their bill—on the Monday I gave the bill—shortly after breakfast Mrs. Norie sent to my shop and said they had not got the bill—I questioned the prisoner, and he said he supposed he had left it at another customer's—I made out another, and in the course of the day they came and said there were ten loaves too many—the first opportunity I had, I questioned the prisoner about the loaves, and he said, "I suppose I forgot to book them"—I said, "Very well, go in the evening and set it right"—he went out and did not return.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had he to take loaves out to other customers? A. Not at that particular time—I am quite sure he said Mrs. Norie wanted ten more loaves—I am sure he did not merely say that he wanted ten.

ANN SAVAGH . I am servant to Mrs. Norie, who lives in Bear-alley—I received fifteen loaves, and they were put down in the book, which I have here—the prisoner brought word in the morning that Mr. Hooke could not spare any more.

Cross-examined. Q. What ire you? A. Mrs. Norie's sister—I had these loaves to sell—we keep no servant—MRS. Norie sometimes takes in the bread herself—the man that brings it makes the entry in the book—I always take care that he enters it—I am always in the shop, and was there the whole day.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1259.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 coat, value 10s., the goods of
John Berry.

JOHN BERRY . I am a builder living in Chapel-street, Stockwell—I left my coat in my chaise on the 9th of April just on one side of the Mansion-house—I was away about half-an-hour, and when I came back it was gone—(produced)—this is it.

JOSEPH CHARLES HOWETT . I am a surveyor, and live in Walbrook—the prosecutor came to my house, and desired one of my clerks to watch the chaise—I saw the prisoner take the coat from the gig—I ran out and took him about a dozen yards off—I have made inquiries, and I believe distress caused him to do it.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined One Month.

1260.
MARY GRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 plate, value 1s., the goods of
Robert Gordon and others.

MAJOR JOHN ABBOTT . I am a private in the first battalion of Grena
dier Guards—I was on duty in Whitehall-gardens, and saw the prisoner come from the Reform Club-house—I saw the print of a plate through her apron—I had seen it previous to that on the sand bin in the yard—I went to the yard, and the plate was gone—I returned and took her with it—she said it was an old broken plate she had picked up—it was not broken then, it is now.
MATTHEW SAUNDERS . I am servant to the Reform Club-house—this
plate is the property of Robert Gordon and others—Robert Gordon is secretary to the Lords of the Treasury.
HENRY BENTLEY (police-constable A 193.) I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I went and picked up bones, and this plate was among some sand.
NOT GUILTY .

1261.
JAMES BARTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 time-piece, value 18s., the goods of
William Sparrowe.

WILLIAM SPARROWE . I keep an auction-room, and live in Smith's-row, New-road—I had a time-piece on the 8th of April—this is it—it had been with me several days for sale—I had seen it about a quarter of an hour before it was missed.

ELIZABETH SAXON . I saw this time-piece at Mr. Sparrowe's on the 8th of April—I saw the prisoner take it up and put it under the left flap of his coat, and go out—I made an alarm—he was brought back with it.

GEORGE DUDNEY . I was at the auction-room on this evening—I heard Saxon call, "That man has stolen a time-piece"—I went, and saw him throw it into a piece of land—I took it up, and gave him into custody.
Prisoner's Defence. I came out with the rush of people, I did not take it.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1262.
JOSEPH HANNEY was indicted
for embezzlement.

CHARLES WYMAN . I keep a public-house in Curzon-street, May-fair. The prisoner was my postman—it was his duty to receive money paid on my account—if he received 1s. 3d. on the 22nd of March, he has not paid it to me, which he ought to have done that day.
MARY FOSBURY . I live in Spring-square, and deal with the prosecutor. The prisoner brought me a pint of beer, and half-a-pint of rum on the 22nd of March—I paid him 1s. 3d. for his master.
Prisoner. I own taking the money, but it only came to 1s. 2d.; the whole money was 5s. 1d.—I used to account to his wife twice a day, and I accounted to her for this.
NOT GUILTY .

1263.
JOHN WILSON RIDOUT was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of March, 1 cream-ewer, value 5l.; 1 bed-tick, value 3s.; 1 set of bed furniture, value 2s.; 1 sofa-cover, value 2s.; 2 castors, value 1s.; and 6 bolts, value 1s.; the goods of
Abraham Soloman, his master.

ABRAHAM SOLOMAN . I am a furniture-broker, and live in Little Queen-street. The prisoner was a French-polisher, and was at my house on the 31st of March—he left that evening, and did not return the next morning as he ought—I lost the cream-ewer on the 31st, and the other property prior to that time—I had used the ewer that day at breakfast—this is it—it has a crest on one side, and initials on the other—(looking at it.)

JOHN DAVIS . I live with Mr. Wells in Queen-street. About ten o'clock that night, the prisoner came to the George public-house—I saw him with the milk jug—I heard Mr. Soloman had lost one, and gave Information.

RICHARD PEARCE . I am potman at the George. The prisoner came on the evening of the 31st of March, into the tap-room, sat down, and threw down some bed-furniture, and in about ten minutes after, he said, "I have
got something at the next house, which I want to get away, I got it from a sale"—he went and got a milk-ewer like this.
Prisoner's Defence. I could not return, as the officer took me, and the bed-tick does not belong to Mr. Soloman.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.

1264.
JANE LACY was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of March, 4 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 10 shillings, 1 watch-guard, value 2s.; and 1 pair of boots, value 7s.; the property of
John Swanson.

JOHN SWANSON . I am a seaman, and lodge in Gravel-lane. On the 25th of March, I went to Bluegate-fields with the prisoner—I had four sovereigns, two half-sovereigns, ten or twelve shillings in silver, and a silver watch-guard—I took off my clothes, put them on a chair, and went to bed—I sent the prisoner for some gin and porter, which she brought—I sent her for a light—she said she had no money—I told her to put her hand into my pocket, to find some coppers among the silver, which she did, she went out, and did not return—I got out of bed, overhauled my things, and found all this property gone, and my shoes—no one else had been in the room—nobody else could have taken them.

GEORGE WILLIAM GRAVES (police-sergeant K 11.) I went to Tothill
fields Bridewell, and saw the prisoner, I told her she was charged with stealing 5l. 10s. and a pair of shoes, from the prosecutor—she said he must be a very false man, she had only taken 3l. 10s., and knew nothing about the shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

1265.
JOHN GRANT was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of April, 1 printed book, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Stencer.
JOHN BROWN . I am shopman to Charles Stencer, a bookseller, in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square. I lost a printed book—this is it.

WILLIAM BUTCHER (police-constable E 51.) About a quarter before eight o'clock, on the 3rd of April, I saw the prisoner pass the prosecu
tor's shop, go on the other side, then cross again—he came, took this book, and walked about twenty yards, I then secured him.
Prisoners Defence. I did not move two yards, when he laid hold of me.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1266.
JOHN DUDLEY,
FREDERICK HOEFLER , and
THOMAS TAYLOR were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of April, 3 loaves of bread, value 7d., the goods of
George Beland; and that Hoefler and Tay
lor had been before convicted of felony.

MARTHA BELAND . I am the wife of George Beland, and live in Char
lotte-street, Whitechapel. About half-past one o'clock, on the 6th of April, I was in my parlour—I heard a rustling at the window, Bowden called me—I went out, and missed three loaves—I ran down Nottingham
place, and saw the three prisoners running—Dudley delivered some loaves to the other two—he was then secured—he said he had done no
thing—I said, "Come back, I will see what you have done"—Hoefler and Taylor got off at that time.
ANDREW BOWDEN . I live in Duke-street. I was in Charlotte-street, near the prosecutor's window—I saw Hoefler open the window, and each
of the prisoners take a loaf—I went and told—MRS. Beland overtook them—they hid the bread—I am sure I saw them each take a loaf.
ROBERT MIDDLETON (police-constable K 216.) I took the prisoners—I do not know what became of the bread.

Hoefler's Defence. I was in Whitechapel about ten o'clock that even
ing, and they took me.

ROBERT CHAMBERS . I produce a certificate of Taylor's former convic
tion, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read—I know Taylor—he is the person.
EDWALD WELSH (police-constable H 180.) I produce a certificate of Hoefler's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—Hoefler is the person.

DUDLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Six Months.

HOEFLER*—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

TAYLOR*—
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years.

1267.
LOUISA PUDDICK and
HESTER CURRY were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April, 154 yards of lace, value 3l. 17s., the goods of
Thomas Hendy.

THOMAS HENDY . I am a laceman, and live in Hereford-place, Com
mercial-road. On the 10th of April, about half-past eleven o'clock, the two prisoners came to my shop and asked my daughter-in-law to serve them—I saw the thread lace box on the counter before them—they asked my daughter to go to the other end of the shop for something else, and while she was gone, Puddick took five cards of thread lace off the counter and gave them to Curry, who concealed them under her right arm, under her shawl—I saw them—I was in the parlour at the back of the shop—I came up and fixed my eye on Curry—I saw she had the lace under her right arm as she was sitting on the seat—seeing she was discovered, she burst into tears, took the lace from under her arm, and put it on the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What were you doing? A. I was about to shave, but had scarcely commenced—I was looking into the shop through a glass window—I could see distinctly what took place on the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Were you about to put the lather on your face? A. Yes—I dare say I was—I was not looking in the looking-glass at the moment I saw the property stolen—my daughter Elisabeth was serving them—Cooper, my shop woman, was in the parlour—there is a looking-glass in the parlour, by which you can see what is going on in the shop—it was not that glass at which I was shaving, but another.

SARAH COOPER . I am shop woman to Mr. Hendy. I was in the parlour and saw the prisoners looking at some lace—MR. Hendy desired me to come out—I saw Curry take the lace from under her right arm, and put it on the counter—that was about five minutes after I came into the shop.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What was your master about? A. Going to shave—he was looking into the shop—I was sitting in the parlour opposite the door—I did not see Puddick take the lace—she had her back to me—I was about a yard from Curry behind the counter, when I saw her take the lace from her shawl under her right arm—I saw it dis
tinctly—she was in front of it.

ELIZABETH BURRELL . The prisoners came to the shop and asked to look at some thread lace—they then asked for some stomachers, and while my back was turned to get them, one of them took the lace out of the box—it was there when I went, and it was gone when I came back—there was 154 yards of it—MR. Hendy came into the shop soon after, and stood behind them watching them—they bought three-quarters of a yard of lace at half-a-crown a yard, and paid for it—they had not bought any before—I saw the lace produced and thrown upon the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Had you not placed these five cards on the counter for them to look at? A. Yes, and missed them on my return—it was impossible to avoid it—they were looking at some others—it is not unusual for one person to hand lace to another, who turns to the light to look at it—I have stated that my father was shaving and looking into a glass at the fire-place which reflected from the shop.

COURT. Q. But you were not in the room where he was? A. No—there were five cards of lace on the counter, but the box was by the side of it—the pieces that were taken were taken from the box—the five remained on the counter.

THOMAS HENDY
re-examined. The box contained from fifty to sixty cards—they were selecting the cards of lace—my eyes were never off them—Puddick had selected them, and she took them from the counter and gave them to the other.
(Puddick received a good character.)

PUDDICK—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

CURRY*—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1268.
JOSEPH WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; 1 purse, value 1s.; 1 shilling, and 1 penny, the property of
William Christie, from the person of
Louisa Christie.

LOUISA CHRISTIE . I am the wife of William Christie, who lives in New North-street, Red Lion-square. I was in St. James's-street, Pall Mall, on the evening of the 9th of April—there was a crowd there—I felt something—I turned and said to the prisoner, who was in a blue coat, "You have robbed me"—he had his left hand in my pocket—he took it out and put it in his own pocket, and made off—I put my hand in and missed my handkerchief and purse from it.
Prisoner. I had not a blue coat on—it was the coat I have on now.
Witness. I am sure you are the man that took it—you ran a few yards, and was brought back by the police.

SMUEL WRIGHT (police-constable P 172.) I watched the prisoner for ten minutes behind the prosecutrix—I saw him put his hand in her pocket, and draw out this handkerchief—he ran about ten yards—he took this hand
kerchief from his pocket and threw it down—I threw him on some steps, and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

1269.
JOHN SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Cooper, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
THOMAS COOPER . I live in Chapel-street, Pentonville. On the evening

of the 8th of April I was in Little Britain—I received information, turned, and saw the prisoner, and accused him of having stolen my handkerchief—he denied it—he was searched in my presence, and this handkerchief found on him—it is mine, and was safe a quarter of an hour before.

Prisoner. Q. Did not a gentleman cross the road, and say, "You have got a gentleman's handkerchief?" then you ran across, and said, "Yes, that is my handkerchief." it was found on the stones. A. It was taken from under your waistcoat.

WELCOME COLE . I was walking opposite the prosecutor. I saw the prisoner and another walking behind the prosecutor—I saw the prisoner raise the tail of his coat, and take the handkerchief—I crossed, and told the prosecutor—I hastened after the prisoner, and took the handkerchief from under his waistcoat.
ADAM SPAREY (City police-constable, No. 36.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person.
JOHN ANDERSON . I am clerk at Giltspur-street prison. The prisoner had three months' imprisonment for that offence.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1270.
CATHERINE COHEN was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 30th of March, of an evil-disposed person, 3 forty-franc pieces, value 4l. 18s.; 19 twenty-franc pieces, value 15l. 10s. 4d.; and 12 imperials, value 9l. 16s.; the monies of
Christian Bager; well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ELIZABETH MORGAN . I am the wife of James Morgan, and keep a beer-shop in Duke's-court, Bow-street. On Monday or Tuesday last the prisoner came to my house with a girl, and called for a pint of ale—they stood and drank it, and offered my daughter a sovereign, as I thought, and asked if I could give change—I said "No," and I told my daughter to go and get change—she went and came back, and said it was a French sove
reign—I said I should like to see one—I took it, and gave it back to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know a person of the name of Thwaite? A. Yes, two or three—one Samuel Thwaite lives in Lascelles-place, and there is Peter Thwaite, who lives with his father, in Market-court, Russell-street—I have known him a good many years, not as an acquaintance, but as a neighbour's child—he is no relation of mine—my daughter married a brother of his—I have been told that he lived with the prisoner—I have not known it—I have not heard him make a statement about this prosecution—he did not offer to make a bet about the result of it, or tell me he wanted to get rid of her—I never heard from him how long he had lived with her, nor that he promised to marry her—I heard of his having thrown himself into the Thames—I saw him last about ten days ago—I never heard him lay a bottle of wine about this—I never saw the prisoner but once before she came to my house for this pint of beer—she was at my daughter's wedding.

CHRISTIAN BAGER (through an interpreter.) I went to a house—I had three forty-franc, nine twenty-franc pieces, and twelve imperials—I saw the prisoner and two more in the house—the prisoner left the room—my money was safe after she left—I afterwards made a complaint of being robbed—the
prisoner came in again—she pointed out ray money to me—I got fourteen pieces out of the thirty-seven—there were two girls on the bed.
NOT GUILTY .

1271.
MARY WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of March, 1 snuff-box, value 1l.; 2 seals, value 16s.; 1 pair of bracelets, value 2s.; 1 clasp, value 1s. 6d.; 2 snaps, value 1s.; 1 cross, value 1s. 6d.; 2 pencil-cases, value 10s.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 3s.; 2 brooches, value 12s.; 3 shirts, value 7s.; 1 handkerchief, value 5s.; 1 watch-guard, value 1s.; 1 buckle, value 2s.; 1 eye-glass, value 6d.; 1 watch-key, value 6d.; and 2 seals, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Na
thaniel M'Phail.
THOMAS NATHANIEL M'PHAIL . The prisoner was servant where I lodged—I have lost a quantity of jewellery—this is mine—(examining some.)
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has not the greater part of it been restored by the prisoner's parents? A. Yes—I am not aware that there is any more missing.
SAMUEL BROOKS . I am apprentice to Mr. Chadwick, a watchmaker. I received this box as a present from the prisoner about five weeks ago she said it was her brother's, add he gave it her.

Cross-examined. Q. And she lent you a volume of Shakspeare, I be
lieve? A. Yes.
THOMAS SILVESTER (police-constable F 103.) I took he—she said she had done wrong, and deserved to be punished.

(The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to main
tain her till she got a situation.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Days.

1272.
SUSAN HARRIS,
WILLIAM JONES , and
WILLIAM HARRIGAN were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April, 6lbs. weight of bacon, value 4s., the goods of
Henry Coe.
HENRY COE . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Fitzroy-square. On the 8th of April, about half-past eight o'clock, these two pieces of bacon were taken from my shop.

GEORGE ANTHONY . I saw the three prisoners in Marylebone-street standing at a cheesemonger's door, about ten yards from yards from Mr. Coe's—they then walked on to Coe's shop—Jones looked in several times, then walked in, and brought something out—Harris stood opposite, and then he went in—I missed Harris, and then I saw Jones give something to Harrigan—they walked on, and Jones whistled—Harris crossed, and tied up the bacon in a handkerchief—I got an officer, who took them.

Jones. He says he saw me go into the shop; it is false. Witness. I have every reason to believe that the boys are the dupes of the female pri
soner—I have seen her about.
Harris's Defence. I did not know the boys before; they gave me the bacon, and asked me to carry it home for them.

HARRIS—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Three Months.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

HARRIGAN—
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Confined Nine Days and
Whipped.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1273.
CHARLES DE CANTAROS was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of March, 1 portmanteau, value 15s.; 2 belts, value 2s.; 1 dagger and case, value 1l. 5s.; 1 printed book, value 6d.; 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 2 snuff-boxes, value 21s.; 1 cigar-box, value 6d.; 1 pair of stock
ings, value 1s.; 2 pairs of socks, value 1s.; 6 shirts, value 14s.; 5 cur
tains, value 3s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 2s.; 7 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 towel, value 6d.; 1 scarf, value 2s.; 2 pairs of gloves, value 2s.; 1 pair of braces, value 1s.; 1 memorandum-book, value 3d.; 1 night-cap, value 3d.; 2 stocks, value 2s.; 1 tobacco-pouch, value 6d.; 3 purses, value 1s.; 2 pairs of trowsers, value 1l.; and 1 coat, value 22.; the goods of
Raphael Moro; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

1274.
JOHN MONTEITH and
ANN MONTEITH were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 24th of March, of certain evil-disposed per
sons, 31bs. weight of mutton, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Seabrook, well knowing the same to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

THOMAS SEABROOK . I am a butcher, and live in Harrow-road, Padding
ton. On the 24th of March a breast of mutton was stolen from me, about half-past twelve o'clock in the day—I was informed of it by a neighbour—I went out, and saw some boys—I followed them—I then went to the pri
soners' room with Ridley, and asked if they had not got a boy there concealed with some meat—they said they had not—I said I was convinced that they had—they said if he was there he must be in the area—I went, and there was no one there—I looked about the room, and found the boy Young in the turn-up bedstead and this meat—John Monteith was sitting by the fire smoking his pipe, and did not say any thing.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did both the prisoners speak to you? A. No, only the woman—I have heard that they are husband and wife.

JOHN YOUNG . I am fourteen years old, and live with my father in Little Carlisle-street—he is a policeman. I know the boy Ridley who stole the meat—I was with him and two others—Ridley took it from the shop, and gave it to me—I was two yards off when he stole it—the prisoners live in Devonshire-street—I took the breast of mutton there—I had not seen the prisoners before, but the other two boys told Ridley to take it there, and I took it—I found the two prisoners there—I set it down, and asked if they would buy it—they said they would—I said I wanted 10d. for it—they said they would give me 8d.—I said I would take 9d., I would not take less—they said they would not give me more than 8d., as they could buy it at a shop for 1s.—the male prisoner was putting his hand into his pocket to pull out the money to pay me 8d., when Ridley and the prosecutor came in—(the female prisoner had dealt with me, but the man was going to pay me)—I saw the policeman have hold of Ridley, and I said to the prisoners, "Here is the butcher, where shall I get to?" and the woman told me to get into the bed—I went into the bed directly, which was turned up.
Cross-examined. Q. You have been tried for this, have you not? A. Yes, and convicted—I was fined 1s., and discharged.
THOMAS SAVORY (police-constable D 58.) I took the prisoners in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you made any inquiry about them? A. I have heard that the man is a watchman, and bears a very good character.

JOHN MONTEITH—
GUILTY. Aged 73.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
—
Confined Six Months.

ANN MONTEITH—
NOT GUILTY .

1275.
THOMAS ROBERTSON was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of February, 4 boxes, value 30s.; 1 bag, value 6d.; 1 drawer, value 2s. 6d.; 30 tablets, value 9l.; 60 paper-knives, value 6l.; 20 fans, value 5s.; 2 knives, value 1s.; and 2 forks, value 1s.; the goods of
Joseph Smith, his master: and
SAMUEL WILKINSON
, for feloniously receiv
ing the same well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute.
&c.; to which Robertson pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.
JOSEPH SMITH . The prisoner Robertson was my errand-boy for four or five weeks—I know nothing of Wilkinson, but part of my property has been discovered, and is here now—what is produced is mine.

GEORGE MONSON . I am a sergeant in the 14th Light Dragoons. On the 29th of February I met the prisoner Wilkinson in the Canteen at Hounslow-barracks—I had never seen him before—I purchased this small paper-knife of him—(looking at it)—he asked me 1s. for it—he had a great number of other things for sale as a sort of pedlar.

JOHN PRICE . I am a servant in the 14th Light Dragoons. I was at Hounslow-barracks, and saw Wilkinson there on the afternoon of the 28th of February—I had seen him before, two years ago last November, when he was in the Blues—he came from the same "town that I do—he stopped with me from the afternoon of the 28th till the 29th, and when he was going away he made my children a present of a small knife and fork each—these are them—as he was going away he dropped this box, and left that with me.

MARY TURNER . I live at Hounslow-barracks. I saw Wilkinson there on the 29th of February—I had never seen him before—he came to the mess kitchen with a number of things—I bought these three work-boxes of him for 10s.—he told me he was a manufacturer of them.

ROBERT MYERS . I am a retailer of beer, and a grocer, and live at Turnham-green. Wilkinson came to my house, and had a pint of beer—he had a number of goods, which he exposed on the table for sale—I said they were very splendid, and I was sorry to see such a sacrifice—I bought nothing of him but this bag (producing it.)

JOHN WILLIAM JONES . I am a pawnbroker, and live at New Brentford. I have three ivory tablets, pawned on the 28th of February by Wilkinson, in the name of John Williams—he said he was the maker and seller of the goods, and he had token nothing all day—I lent 2s. 6d. on them.

JOHN GILBERT . I am a shoemaker, and live at West-place, Turnham-green. I saw Wilkinson in a beer-shop—he offered me this drawer (pro
ducing it), and asked if I would give him a pot of beer for it, which I did.
HENRY JOHN BEAUMONT . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Edgeware-road. I took in two tablets of Wilkinson on the 28th of February.
JOHN HUGHES . I am a pawnbroker. I produce one tablet, which I
took in pledge of Wilkinson on the 28th of February in the name of John Williams.

Wilkinson's Defence. I came out of the country on the 26th of Febru
ary And on the 27th I was at a public-house with some friends about ten o'clock; I met with the prisoner Robertson there; I heard them talking about a raffle for an accordion, they put my name down for one; I saw Robertson again that night, he raid he made fancy goods and toys, and we might get a living by selling them, that he could get plenty of goods; I said I would sell them; the next morning, at ten minutes before eight o'clock, he came to my lodgings, and said he had got some things; I went and pawned some of them, then went down the road, and sold the rest.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1276.
THOMAS MAGEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Robert William Elliott, from his person.

ROBERT WILIAM ELLIOTT . I am an accountant in the Excise-office. On the 9th of April, between four and five o'clock, I was in Shoreditch with two ladies—we stopped at a jeweller's shop window to look at some jewellery—I had a handkerchief in my pocket, and I had scarcely got to the Window when I saw the ruffling of my handkerchief over my left shoulder—I turned, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand close behind me—I pursued him—he carried it some distance, and then threw it down—the officer took it up—I pursued, and he was stopped—this is my handkerchief—(looking at it.)
Prisoner. I was not behind him at all—I never saw him till I was taken. Witness. I never lost sight of him.

MILES DOWLING (police-constable H 135.) On Thursday last I saw the prisoner take this handkerchief in his hand, probably from the prose
cutor—he ran down Bateman's-row—I pursued him till he threw it down—I took it up, and followed till he was taken.
