Prisoner's Defence. I was going to look for work; some person stopped me, and somebody said, "That is the boy that took the handker
chief;" I had never seen the gentleman.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1277.
JOHN GROUT was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

WILLIAM SQUIRE . I am a manufacturer of manifold-writers. Mr. Thomas Varty, a stationer, in the Strand, deals with me—I had a recollec
tion of seeing the prisoner as having come from Mr. Varty—on the 13th of March he came and had two of our writers to show to a gentleman in Piccadilly, which I delivered to him—he came again in the afternoon for another, but I had in the meantime received information, and secured him—he told me he had come from Mr. Varty, and on that credit I gave him the two Writers, thinking Mr. Varty had sent for them.

THOMAS VARTY . I am a bookseller and stationer. I deal with Mr. Squire—the prisoner lived a little better than three years ago in our ser
vice—I did not send him, on the 13th of March, for these writers—he had no authority from me to get them.
JAMES COLLINS . I am a pawnbroker. I took in one manifold-writer of the prisoner on the 13th of March—this is it.
GEORGE FARMER . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this other writer of the prisoner on the 13th of March.

Prisoner's Defence. I was out of a situation; I obtained them, being in distress, for the purpose of paying my rent; I thought I should be able to return them, as I expected some money the next Saturday morning.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1278.
JAMES MALOY,
RICHARD BUTLER,
JAMES MEAD , and
HELEN BURKE , were indicted for
assaulting a policeman in the discharge of his duty.

MALOY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BUTLER—
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined Three Months.

MEAD—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six weeks.

BURKE—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.

p.hi: Second Jury, Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1279.
MARY FANN was indicted
for a common assault.
(The Prosecutor did not appear.)
NOT GUILTY .

1280.
JOHN HARRISON was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JONATHAN PEARSON . I am an ironmonger, in partnership with Thomas and John Pearson. I deal with Mr. Griffiths—on the 26th of March the prisoner came and said he wanted one of the best bottle-jacks—I got him one to look at—he asked the price, and said it was for Mr. Griffiths, of No. 2, Burton-crescent—he said he would have that one, and asked to see a lamp which was in the window—he said it was just the sort of article Mr. Griffiths had been speaking about—I wished to send it home, but he said he would take them, and said, "That is an excellent guard you had put up in Mr. Griffiths's winery"—I let him have the articles, believing he came from Mr. Griffiths—I had some recollection of having seen him before.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What pas the value of the bottle-jack? A. 14s., and the lamp 7s. 6d.

THOMAS PEARSON . On the 26th of March, after the prisoner had been with my brother, he came and said he wanted the lamp he had just looked at—I said, "Which do you mean?"—he pointed to one on the counter, and said it was for Mr. Griffiths—I said, "You had better let us send it"—he said, "No, you had better let me take it," and I gave it to him—between half-past four and five o'clock he came again for a dozen table knives and forks, he said Mr. Griffiths had a party that day, and they were all in a bustle—I asked what sort be would have—he said what Mr. Griffiths had were balance ones—he selected a dozen at 36s., and took them away with him—in two hours suspicions were raised, and I went to see Mr. Griffiths—I parted with the goods, believing he came from Mr. Griffiths—he also said to me, "That was an excellent guard you put up a twelve-month ago."

GEORGE STOKEHOUSE GRIFFITHS . I am a solicitor. I deal with Pearson and Co.—I did not authorise the prisoner to go for these articles—I knew nothing about it—I never received the goods—he did not live
with me—I have known him some years—he is a connexion of mine by marriage, and knew I dealt with Mr. Pearson—he bore a very excellent character till lately.
WILLIAM RIDEWOOD . I am a broker and curiosity-dealer, in Cleveland-street. I bought this bottle-jack, and lamp, on the 26th, of the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. What did you give for them? A. 5s. for the two—I had seen the prisoner two or three times before—he had sold me trifling things on each occasion—I think the time before that he sold me an old box, and some old newspapers—I gave him 1s. or 1s. 6d. for the box—he sold me an old shot-belt and powder-flask for 1s. together—I do not recollect what I bought of him besides—I do not keep an account of what I buy—he was dressed as he is now—he brought me the bottle-jack about two o'clock, and the lamp at the same time—I know these knives were offered to me, between five and six o'clock—I said I did not want them, and offered 5s. for them.
JOHN DOWLING . I am a clothes-salesman, in Cleveland-street. I bought the knives of the prisoner, for 1s. they were quite new.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Yes, several times—I bought some trowsers of him, and other things.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

1281.
RICHARD GOULD, alias Arthur Nicholson,
was indicted
for the wilful murder of
John Templeman.

ELIZABETH THORNTON . I am single, and live with my mother, in a cottage in Pocock's-fields, Islington—MR. Templeman lived in a cottage facing us. On Tuesday morning, the 17th of March, I went to Mr. Tem
pleman's cottage, at half-past eight o'clock, with two sheets of writing-paper—I knocked at the door, but received no answer—MR. Templeman used to sleep in the further room from a cottage inhabited by Mrs. Jarvis, and the further room from the door—the door opens into one room, and then you go into the other—there is a window to the bed-room—when I received no answer I went to the bed-room window, and found it shut down as usual—there was a short curtain to it inside—I was too short to see over the cur
tain—I then went to the sitting-room window, and found it open—I then returned home, and told my mother what I had observed.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How far is your cottage from Mr. Templeman's? A. It may be about a yard, as far as I can call to mind—it faces it—our door is not opposite his door—it is about as far from it as from me to the bench of this Court—the window which was open looks towards our cottage—there is no yard before it—it is all one piece of ground—there are palings all round our house, and Mr. Templeman's too—our bed-room window faces towards Mr. Templeman's—I recollect that there was a pane of glass broken for some time in Mr. Templeman's window, and there was a piece of paper over it, when my mother used to go backwards and forwards, but there was not that morning, it had been thrust through—there are three cottages within about the same distance of Mr. Templeman's as ours—there are four cottages standing together, Jarvis's, ours, Mr. Templeman's, and Mrs. Downes's—MR. Mustow's cottage is at the back—that makes five—it was a beautiful moon-light night the night before I went—I think it was frosty—the ground was dry by the window where I was standing—it
was more like clay than gravel—I think it was soft—I did not look to see if there were any foot-marks—I went home directly, and told my mother.

MARY THORNTON . I am the mother of the last witness—she resides with me in a cottage in Pocock's-fields. On Tuesday morning, the 17th of March, I sent her to Mr. Templeman's cottage with some writing-paper—she returned, and made a communication to me—I then went to Mr. Temple
man's cottage, and knocked at the door—no answer was returned—I then went to the bed-room window—it was quite closed—there was a curtain and drawn-blind to it—I looked over the curtain, and saw the bed—there was no one in it—I saw Mr. Templeman on the floor, about a yard from the bed, lying with his feet towards the fire-place, and his head towards the parlour door—I then went round to the sitting-room window, and found it was open—I had known Mr. Templeman nearly four years—three years and a half full he had been in the neighbourhood—for about two months I had been in the habit of washing and charing for him, fetching his errands, and such like—the parlour window was always closed previous to this morning—I never saw it open—it used to be fastened with a little button just below where it was broken—it had been broken a long time—it was quite a small hole, nearly close to the button—there was no difference in the hole that morning, except that the paper was gone, and, I believe, a bit of glass—it had been fastened with a bit of glass, and paper on it—when the paper was gone any body could put their hand in and open it—the window is quite big enough for a man to get in when it is open—I had been to the house the evening before, at a quarter before six o'clock, and left about five minutes before six o'clock—he usually went to bed about six o'clock—he never was up afterwards, unless any body was there—he did not have any beer on Monday evening, to my knowledge—I have known the prisoner about four or five months—he had been pot-man at the Barnsbury Castle public-house—I have seen him serve Mr. Templeman with beer—I know the Jarvises—they live nearly close to Mr. Temple
man's—it is one of the four cottages—I have heard that the prisoner was on visiting terms at Jarvis's, and I have seen him go in repeatedly—I think it must be nearly a fortnight before this affair that I saw him there—I did not see any thing of Mrs. Jarvis on the Monday evening—I saw her in the fore-part of the day at her own door, or else in the ground—she had her child with her.

Q. Did you see any money that day at Mr. Templeman's cottage? A. Yes, he showed me some, and told me had been receiving some rents—it was silver, and was in a little mahogany box—I had never seen that box before—he put it on the table where he took it from to show me the money—the table stood in the middle of the room—he had never shown me any money before.

Cross-examined. Q. You have said to-day you have seen the prisoner serve Mr. Templeman with beer; is that quite correct? A. Quite—I ne
ver said I thought I had—I might have said to, but I can say that I did see him, and that will settle it—I might have said I thought, although I was certain—the prisoner used to come round to serve the neighbours with beer—it was seldom I had any beer, but when I did he served me—there are four cottages besides Mr. Templeman's—my son-in-law and daughter live with me—I do not take lodgers occasionally—we have no room for ourselves hardly—Mr. and Mrs. Downes live in their cottage—she does not take lodgers that I know—how should I know other people's

affairs?—I have not seen a strange man going in and out of Downes's cot
tage, to my knowledge, unless it is acquaintances going, who are strangers to me—I do not know what sort of persons they are—I never trouble my head about it—I saw people go in there—I do not trouble my head with my neighbours' concerns—I have not seen any strangers going in and out of Mrs. Palmer's, or Mrs. Mustow's—they might have visitors—I never take notice of other people's affairs—I might have seen people going in and out—I do not trouble my head about it.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You were examined at the Police-office and be
fore the Coroner? A. Yes—I never mentioned having seen the prisoner at Mr. Templeman's to any body.

FRANCIS CIPRANI . I am a night-watchman at Sadler's Wells theatre, and live with my mother-in-law, Mrs. Thornton. I used to work for Mr. Templeman, digging in his garden—on Monday evening, the 16th of March, I received 7s. from him for my labour—it was six shillings and two six-pences—I received it about a quarter or twenty minutes before six o'clock, to the best of my recollection—I know a man named Jarvis, and I have seen his wife—I saw her, about half-past four o'clock that day, come away from her cottage, and go to Mr. Templeman's cottage, and stand just by the door talking to him, to the best of my recollection, for five or ten minutes—I did not see what became of her then—I was busy at work—I missed her from the door—I did not take notice which way she went.

Cross-examined. Q. You were first taken up on this charge, is that true?—A. Yes—on Tuesday, between twelve and one o'clock, I was dis
charged next morning before the Magistrate—no evidence was given against me—the Magistrate said he discharged me without a stain on my character—I accounted for how I passed my time—I brought forward the call-boy at our theatre, to prove that I let him out at half-past three o'clock—I rent the cottage myself, but keep my mother to look after it—I do not know that Mr. Templeman kept any tools in his house—he called me in that morning, and sent me to fetch a basket of coals for him—he used to sit in the parlour, opposite the window—I never saw him sit with that window open.

COURT. Q. When Mr. Templeman paid you the 7s., did he take it out of a little mahogany box? A. Yes, it stood on the table—I saw a quantity of half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences in it—that was between a quarter and twenty minutes before six o'clock—I was not at home when the girl came to inform my mother-in-law of the window being open—I did not leave Sadler's Wells theatre till about five minutes to nine o'clock in the morning.

COURT to ELIZABETH THORNTON. Q. When you went back to tell your mother the window was open, what did she say? A. She said, "Good God! I hope nobody has got in, and murdered the old gentleman"—that was before she went to the house.

WILLIAM KEAR (police-constable N 131.) On Tuesday morning, the 17th of March, about twenty minutes after eleven o'clock, I received information, and went to Mr. Templeman's cottage, in company with two surgeons—I found the door fast inside—I went in through the sitting-room window, and opened it—it was single-locked—I unlocked it, and let the, surgeons in—it was locked from the inside, and the key was in the door—there are two rooms to the house—there is only one front door, and a door to each room—there is no back door—the two windows are in front of the cottage, one on each side of the door—there is no back window, and no way of get
ting

out of the house behind—you must come either through the door or one of the front windows—there is a wooden partition between the two rooms—I saw the body of Mr. Templeman lying on his back on the floor, not far from the bed—his room is small—his feet laid towards the fire-place, and his head towards the window—his hands were tied across with a cord in front of him—there was one cord round the wrists, and a smaller cord tied round the other cord—a stocking was over his eyes, and tied be
hind—there was another stocking on the floor—both stockings were co
vered with blood—I suppose the blood on the one over his eyes came off the floor where he lay—there was blood on both sides of the stocking—Sergeant Collins came to the cottage soon after, and he found some of the deceased's clothes on a sofa—he had nothing on but a shirt—I did not observe whether it was a night-shirt or day-shirt—his legs were not tied—there was a chest of drawers in the sitting-room—the two top-drawers had been forced open, it appeared to me, by a chisel—in one of the drawers was a box open, which Collins has—I do not know what wood it is made of—I suppose it is mahogany—I should think it is about six inches by ten or eleven—there was nothing in it—in the bed-room Mr. Roe, the surgeon, picked up a tooth off the pillow, and one off the chair, and I myself picked one up off the floor—there was a pool of blood close to the body—the body lay on the top of the blood—most of the blood was about the head—the tooth was in part of the blood close to the head—the pillow of the bed was all bloody—the sheets were not—the most blood was on the pillow, and the rest on the floor.

Cross-examined. Q. I wish to know exactly what time it was you went to Mr. Templeman's cottage? A. About twenty minutes after eleven o'clock—I went at the request of Mr. Roe, the surgeon—my beat is not in Pocock's-fields—it was Harris's, No. 112, beat that morning—he is not here—he went on duty at nine o'clock that morning, and would continue there until two—I do not know who he relieved at nine—there was a man who left at nine—he went on duty at six—the man he relieved would be on duty from nine the night before till six in the morning—I do not believe that either of the men who were there that night and morning are here—I know Pocock's-fields—there are a great number of cottages there—they are principally inhabited by a working class of people—MR. Templeman's cottage is surrounded by other cottages.

COURT. Q. Then you don't know who the men were—what is their beat, how far does it go? A. It is called the Liverpool-road beat—it be
longs to that beat—I came on at nine o'clock that morning, and was going off at two o'clock—I was at Highbury—I do not know how near the police
man in the Liverpool-road beat would have to go to the place where this happened—I heard him say he passed the cottage about ten o'clock, and heard nothing then—I examined the deceased's wrists—I did not observe them when the cord was taken off—I cannot tell whether the cord was put on after or before he was dead—he was bruised about the knees, and on the breast—the pillow-case was all over blood—it appeared that a blow had been given him while he was lying there, by the tooth being on the pillow.

MARY THORNTON
re-examined. Q. To whom did you first give any information concerning the state in which you found the cottage? A. To my son's landlady, a person named Pershouse, in the next cottage to ours, about three minutes after I first found it out—my son returned from the

theatre about ten or twenty minutes after nine o'clock in the morning—I had heard Mr. Templeman mention that he had a grandson living in Mor
timer-street, and I knew him well—as soon as my son came home from the theatre, I sent him to give information to Mr. Templeman—that was in consequence of what the deceased had told me during his life time.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see Mr. Templeman's body through the window? A. I did—I said so to Mrs. Pershouse—she did not accompany me to the window, and I told the baker, who came up with Mr. Temple
man's bread—I do not know the policeman who was on duty at the time—I never saw him—I have seen policemen there, but do not know who was there that morning—they very seldom came there—I did not attempt to find one.

EDWARD ROE . I am a surgeon, and live in Brown-buildings, Islington. I accompanied Mr. Lord and a policeman to Mr. Templeman's cottage, about twenty minutes after eleven o'clock—the policeman got through the window, opened the door, and let us in—I saw the deceased with only a shirt on, lying with his feet towards the fire-place, and his head towards the door of the room—the body was in the bed-room, towards the door, which is between the two rooms—he was lying on his back, rather inclining to the left side, lacing the window—his eyes were firmly bandaged with a stocking—if he had been alive, he could not have seen—there was a good deal of blood on the stocking, which I think must have been saturated with the blood on the floor, after it was tied on his eyes—I have no doubt his head had fallen on the floor, and the stocking got into the blood—his hands were securely tied by a cord in this posture—(describing it)—a small cord secured the other cord fastened between the wrists, through a noose in the cord, to make it more secure—I did not notice the wrists then—I did after the cord was removed, and they were galled, and the hands and nails blue—that would unquestionably show that it had been put on during life—I have no doubt he struggled—the blueness would be occasioned by the pressure of the cord—I observed several bruises on his face, a severe blow over the left temple, and a cut on the nose—the lower jaw was fractured on both sides—I observed four clean cuts on the back of the head, and one or two bruises on the breast bone, in conjunction with the collar-bone—his knees were much abraised, rubbed up, as he had, no doubt, been struggling on the floor—there was some blood on the floor immediately under the deceased's head—I should say perhaps ten ounces—the wounds would most likely continue to bleed some time—there was no contused wound on the left temple to cause the blood—I have no doubt a good deal of the blood came from the jaw, and also the clean cuts on the back of the head—the blow on the temple was most probably given by a blunt round instrument, similar to a policeman's staff—it might be done by a piece of wood—the same instrument might have produced the fracture of the jaw, and one blow might produce both fractures—I think the wound on the nose was from a kick, or something of that description, not done by a sharp instrument—the wounds on the back of the head were inflicted by a very sharp instrument.

COURT. Q. Were they inflicted as with a knife, as if a person had cut, or a hatchet, as if they had struck? A. Neither—I should say like a chisel, as if a chisel had been struck on the back of the head.

MR. JONES. Q. Did you find any teeth? A. I found one on the pillow, with a great deal of blood round it, and another on a chair, with a few spots of blood—I was present when a third was found by the police
man

—I examined the jaw, and found three teeth had been forced from the sockets—they were not front, but tide teeth—I think that was very probably done by the blow which produced the fractures—there were se
veral blows about the mouth, and I think one while he was lying in bed, from the circumstance of the tooth being found on the pillow, and the blood there—the tooth on the chair was as if it had fallen out when he got out of bed—I found a small piece of stick, about two inches and a half or three inches long, with hair attached to it, and saturated with blood—it was the hair of the head—it was dark hair—I can scarcely call it grey—this is the piece of splinter—(produced)—there is hair on it now—a kick from the heel or toe of a shoe might have made the cut on the nose, if there were nails in it, and I think it might be done by a shoe or boot without nails—from the appearance of the body when I saw it, I should judge it had been dead fire or six hours—it retained a little warmth about the region of the heart—the body was quite cold—the time in which a body gets cold depends occasionally on the kind of death the person meets with—a body has retained warmth occasionally two days after death—ten or eleven hours is not at all an unusual time—I have no doubt, had the body remained in bed, it would have been warm a long time after it was—MR. Lord accompanied me—he was also present at the post mortem examination—the injuries which I saw on the body, produced death—I have no doubt the death was owing to the violence I have de
scribed.
COURT. Q. How was the stocking fastened round the head? A. It was tied in a knot twice—the knot was formed in the stocking itself—the blow on the temple was above the stocking, over the temple.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it your judgment, as a man of experience, that the body had been dead about five or six hours? A. It is—I should ra
ther say a body would be more likely to retain heat two days where the party came to his death by violent means—a body would of course be more likely to get cold on the floor than in bed—it was a very cold night on Monday, and morning too—I should think there was not sixteen ounces of blood altogether on the pillow and floor.

Q. I believe the piece of stick is mahogany? A. I am no judge—it is saturated with blood, and the character of the wood is altered—it is splin
tered off a round stick—there is no doubt of it.

MR. JONES. Q. In your judgment, would the blows you saw on the deceased occasion instant death? A. I believe the blow over the left temple would occasion instant death—I did not observe whether there was any matting or carpet on the floor—he might have been dead more than five or six hours—it is mere matter of opinion—saw nothing to render it improbable that he had been dead a longer time.

COURT. Q. It may have been fifteen, ten, or five or six, but it must have been five or six, that is what you mean? A. Yes, it could not have been less than five or six—I do not know whether it might have been fifteen, it is a very difficult question to answer—I should rather not pledge myself to a few hours, more or less.

ALFRED LORD. I am a surgeon, and live in Trinidad-place, Islington. I was present at Mr. Templeman's cottage with Mr. Roe, and saw the state in which the body was—I attended the post mortem examination—in my judgment he died of the wounds I saw—the blow on the left temple would alone be sufficient to produce death—it produced concussion of the brain, and extravasation of blood—he would not be able to stir after that,

the same blow producing a fracture of the skull, he could not struggle af
terwards—the struggling with the arms and knees must have been before—after the blow which fractured the jaw there might have been a good deal of struggling.

COURT. Q. Did the deceased appear to be an athletic strong man? A. He appeared to have been so at one period of life, and from my observa
tion of his body he was rather a stout man—he appeared rather a strongish man, and one who would struggle a good deal, I think—the hands were blue below the cord—the hands and nails—I do not think one man could have tied his hands unless another held them.

JOHN COLLINS (police-sergeant.) I went to Mr. Templeman's cottage on. Tuesday morning, and was there with the surgeons—I have produced the splinter of wood—it was cut at the police-office—I have had it examined, according to the prisoner's request, by a turner, who gave his opinion that it is "red saunders"—he described it as a very heavy close wood, coming from New South Wales—I searched the drawers in the deceased's sitting-room—the top drawer on the left hand side had been broken open apparently by a chisel or small crow-bar or something—I found in it two boxes, a quantity of papers, and two notes of the Bank of Elegance—one for 50l. and the other for 5l.—(producing them)—this is the mahogany box—it has a lock to it—it is not broken—it was shut when I found it, but unlocked—I found the key of it in the deceased's trowsers pocket—I do not think any violence had been offered to the lock—there are also a quantity of papers, bills, and memorandums—I found no money in the drawers, but in his trowsers pocket was a purse with three sixpences—that was in the same pocket with the key—the papers were apparently tumbled about a good deal—these notes, folded up in this way look like notes of the Bank of England—I thought they were so when I first found them—behind the door of the sitting room I found a chopper and a hammer in the corner between the outer door and the bed-room door—I do not think they had been used—I also found a hammer in the cupboard on the top of some clothes—that did not appear to have been used—I found no piece of wood except this—I found no weight except two clock weights—they were round at the bottom and flat at the top—they were in the further cor
ner of the sitting room, attached to the clock—I did not find any other weights in the bed-room.

Cross-examined. Q. How many persons have you taken up on this charge? A. There have been four persons, Jarvis and his wife, Ciprani, and the prisoner—Pocock's-fields is included in my duty—I was on duty on the Monday night—I did not visit Pocock's-fields—Thomas Peacock is the man who was on duty there—he is not here—Harris came on duty at nine o'clock—I do not know who went on duty between six and nine o'clock—I know Pocock's fields—I should think Mr. Templeman's cottage is a mile, or nearly so, from the Angel, at Islington.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How far is it from the Rainbow public-house? A. About a quarter of a mile.

JANE LOVETT . I am the wife of Jonathan Lovett, and keep an eating-house at No. 2, Northern Buildings, Somer's Town. We occupied the house as tenant to Mr. Templeman—on Monday the 16th of March Mr. Tem
pleman called on me at a quarter before twelve o'clock—I had known him about three years—he appeared generally poorly in the winter, he had bet
ter health in the summer—he appeared rather poorly that day—he had a

cold, I imagine—I paid him 3l. that morning—it consisted of five or six half-crowns—I am positive there were five, and one half-sovereign, the rest in shillings, and to the best of my knowledge six sixpences.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know where you got that money? A. I took it in business at different times—I took the whole of it within two days in our shop.

HANNAH MORGAN . I live at No. 18, Skinner-street, Somer's Town—I knew the deceased—he called on me on the 16th of March at half-past eleven o'clock in the morning, and asked me to lend him 3l., which I did—I gave him fourteen half-crowns and twenty-five shillings—he gave me 1s. for apiece of mutton to carry home to make him some soup—he dined with us, and left at half-past three o'clock—he seemed in very low spirits and bad health, labouring under a very bad cold.

COURT. Q. Did he give you any reason why he borrowed the money? A. He said he wanted it to make up an account of money—he left at a quarter before twelve o'clock, and came in again and dined with us after
wards.

MR. JONES. Q. Did he ask you to lend him the 3l. before he went away, or afterwards? A. He asked for it as soon as he returned to dine, which was about a quarter before twelve, or from that to twelve—I do not live near him—he left at half-past three o'clock in the afternoon—Skinner-street leads into the New-road, nearly opposite Judd-street—I cannot tell how far that is from Pocock's fields—I never was there, only at the Barns
bury Castle public-house—I suppose it is two miles from there—I know Mrs. Lovett—she lives about three doors from me—he gave me the shilling after he asked for the 3l.

JANE LOVETT
re-examined. I did not observe whether he had any other money about him when I paid him the 3l. for the rent.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did he put it? A. In his right hand trowsers pocket.

JOHN BUSH . I am a labourer, and live in Goodwin-street, Barnsbury-park. I had a cottage in Pocock's-fields, called Spring Cottage—about seven months ago the deceased offered me 25l. for it—he never brought any money forward—we did not come to any agreement at that time—I saw him about a week or nine days after—there was an agreement between my wife and him—he said he would give me 25l. if I would take it—I said it was no use, I wanted 30l.—we only had one conversation on the subject—it was against his own gate—I stood outside and he inside—I mentioned to several people about what had taken place between Mr. Templeman and myself about the cottage.
COURT. Q. This conversation took place between you and him alone? A. Yes.
Cross-examined. Q. How far from Mr. Templeman's cottage do you live? A. I suppose two hundred yards.

BENJAMIN HAWKINS . I keep a beer-shop in Bride-street, Islington, not far from Mr. Templeman's cottage—I knew him—I do not remember any communication between Bush and Mr. Templeman about a cottage—I saw a sum of money with Mr. Templeman at the time he was about to buy a cottage—I do not know how much it was—it is as much as three or four months ago.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know John Bush? A. Yes—that is not the circumstance I refer to.
COURT. Q. Then this money had no reference to Bush's cottage? A. No, it was for Mr. Game's cottage.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you know Jarvis's cottage? A. Yes—I knew Mrs. Jarvis and the prisoner—I saw him at Mrs. Jarvis's once, sitting by the fire—I do not know whether he was smoking—it it two or three months ago.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you happen to know a man named Henry Wright? A. Yes—I believe he is a pot-man—he lodged at Allen's at the same time as Gould lodged there—that is a good while ago, I should think about last Christmas—Wright was out of employ then—I do not know where he is pot-man—when I first knew him he was at Mr. Stroud's, at the King's Arm's public-house, Liverpool-road—that is twelve months ago, I believe—it is about a quarter of a mile from Pocock's-fields—he was pot-man there—I think it was after that that he went to lodge at Allen's—I cannot recollect distinctly the time he lodged there—I am not sure whether it was before Christmas or after—I do not know how long he lived there—he very seldom frequented my beer-shop, he did once now and then to take a glass of porter—I do not know any other place besides Stroud's where he lived—he was a good bit out of employ, I know, but how long I could not positively tell—I have not seen him about Pocock's-fields lately with beer—I did at the time he lived at Stroud's—he was not living there at the time I heard this about the money, it was before that—I do not know whe
ther he was living at Allen's at that time—I cannot say.
MR. JONES. Q. You say Wright and the prisoner lodged together at Allen's. A. Yes—I do not know whether they were intimate friends—I do not recollect that I ever saw them together away from Allen's.

JOSEPH MUSTOW . I live at a cottage at the back of Mr. Temple-man's, close to his—I do not know the prisoner, but I have seen him about with beer from the Barnsbury Castle public-house where he was pot-man—I cannot say how long it is since he left there—I know I took beer of him before Christmas, but I do not think I have since—I do not know whether he supplied Mr. Templeman with beer—I have seen him about the cottages supplying people with beer—I knew Mr. Templeman very well—I have heard that he was in the habit of talking to people about his money, and he has showed it to me several times—he has paid me small sums of money—he generally took it out of his pocket—he took out more than he wanted—he appeared fond of showing his money—on the Tuesday before he was murdered he showed me this 50l. note—it was doubled up so that I could just see the amount at the corner—it was in his room—he went to the drawer and fetched it out to show it me—I did not mention the circumstance to any body till after his death—I have seen the prisoner at Mrs. Jarvis's, when he lived at the Barnsbury Castle public-house—I cannot say that I have seen him there since, or in the neighbour
hood—I have two dogs—I keep one at the end of my house where I keep my pigs—that is just at the back of Mr. Templeman'a cottage—it is always out at night chained up—he is a sort of lurcher—any body he knows may do any thing with him, but to strangers he is not so civil—I kept that dog there while the prisoner was at the Barnsbury Castle—the prisoner was not acquainted with the dog—I do not think he knew him—he might have seen him, but not to be near him—I do not think the prisoner was ever on my premises.
Cross-examined. Q. When were you subpoenaed to attend here? A. Last night—that was the first time I was applied to.

COURT. Q. Did your dog make any noise on the night of the 16th? A. No—the dog was about as far from the window at which the persons got into the house, as across this court, or half as far again—I am sure the dog would begin to bark at a stranger at that distance, if he could hear his foot
steps, but it would be ten to one if the dog heard them, because that win
dow is in front, and the dog was behind.

HENRY WRIGHT . I am potman at the Duchess of Kent public-house, Devereux-street, Dover-road, where I have been seven weeks—it is about four miles from Mr. Templeman's cottage—I have known the prisoner from seven to eight months—I saw him on the 12th or 13th of last March, I am not positive which—I think it was the 12th, Thursday—he came to the Duchess of Kent public-house about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, and called fur half-a-pint of porter, and put down a penny, saying he had no more money—I did not take the money—I brought him a pint of porter—I then went out to deliver my beer—I returned about half-past eight o'clock—the prisoner was then standing on the outside, opposite the house, talking to a young man, a potman in the neighbourhood, named Richard Squires—there was no conversation between them after I came up—we had some porter together—as soon as we had had the pot of porter between us three, the prisoner and I walked up the street together—while we were walking together he said he had been ill, and was without money, and for want of money he was getting worse—he stated that he knew an old man who had got money—I asked him how he knew he had got money—he said he had heard he had bid 25l. for a cottage, and he had flashed a 50l. note, and said if that was not enough he had got more—the prisoner said that he had put the notes into a drawer, and it would be like a gift to him, for he knew where to put his hand on it—he said he should like to have a right one along with him—I said, "A right one!"—he said, "Yes, a right one, or I could do it myself"—I asked him where the old gentleman lived—he said, "Oh, not far."
Q. Not far from when? A. From where Gould lived.
COURT. Q. Did he say so? A. Yes; he said, not far from him, that it, signifying where Gould lived—he said, "Not far from home"—those were the words be used.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Now, is that all you remember of what passed, or was any thing else said? A. That is all I remember—when he was in the tap-room he named to me that he had been to a publican whom he once lived with, and that he should endeavour to get a situation, and try that man if he would give him a character, that he would send to him—that was before I walked with him—he said nothing further than I have stated with reference to the old gentleman's money.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know where Mr. Templeman lived? A. Yes, in Pocock's-fields, at the back of Liverpool-terrace—a sawyer lived in the next cottage to Mr. Templeman's when I served him—I do not know who lives in it now—I think the sawyer's name was William Izod—he worked in the City-road—I served him—I served most of them near Mr. Templeman's cottage, all round the field—I served the principal of the cottages—I think there were not ten persons who did not deal with me when I carried beer round there—nobody lived with Mr. Templeman then—I do not know who took care of his house—this cottage was build
ing

at the time, and after Izod left, he lived in this cottage till his cottage was built—MR. Tiffin was building this cottage for him while he lived in Izod's—he took possession of the new cottage about two years back—I have known him as long as that—that is the only cottage into which he shifted—when I first knew him I was living at Mr. Ralph's, the William the Fourth public-house, at the corner of Park-street and Minerva-place—I left there because I got another situation—I did not like it—there was no other reason for my leaving—I went after that to the Craven Arms pub
lic-house, Bayswater—I was about twenty-six weeks at Mr. Ralph's the first time—I did not go with a character to the other place—I was eleven months at the Craven Arms public-house—after leaving there I went to work for Mr. Ralph a week, till he got a man, and then I went to the Hope and Anchor public-house, Islington—the landlord left the house, and Mr. Walton took it, and there were a few words between us, and I left—there was no charge against me—the words were about stopping out a few hours—I stopped out between four and eight o'clock—I went away of my own accord—the words were with Mr. Walton, who keeps the house—there had been no charge against me of any kind—there has been a charge, but it was not from Mr. Walton—it was from the Duke of York public-house, Glou
cester-street—I asked permission to go out; while I was out, a cash-box was lost, and when I returned home I was taken up on suspicion, and charged with stealing it—that might be between four and five years ago—there has been nothing further—I never was in custody before, nor yet charged with any thing—I lived at the City of London public-house—I was not in custody respecting any thing there—it it at the corner of Syd
ney-street and Dalby-terrace—I left there to take a beer-shop, after nine years' service—I left of my own accord—there was a cellar there—nothing was said about my conduct in that cellar—that I swear—that is somewhere about the time after I came out of Hatton-garden office—I went to live there again—I lived there about ten months—I opened the beer-shop be
fore I went to the Duke of York public-house, but it did not succeed—I know Mr. Jarvis's cottage very well.

Q. How long before the night Mr. Templeman lost his life, were you in Pocock's-fields do you think? A. On the 9th or 10th I was there—I went to visit Mr. Allen of Wilson-cottage—I had lodged there some time before—there are two rooms in Allen's cottage and, an old back kitchen, and a wash-house adjoining it—there is about half an acre of garden—the privy is in the wash-house, adjoining the bed-room—you can go from the parlour into the little, kitchen into it, and you can go into the garden to get to it.

Q. You mentioned something about what the prisoner said about a drawer, do you mean to say he said that? A. Yes—I recollected that in my statement at the time I was at Hatton-garden at my last evidence—I think I recollected it at the time I was at Hatton-garden—I am certain I did—I have been twice to Hatton-garden—the first time was on a Satur
day—the Saturday after Mr. Templeman's body had been found on the Tuesday—I did not recollect it when I first went—I do not know any thing of this little mahogany box—I am not positive that I ever heard of a mahogany box—I think, but I have never mentioned it, because I was not positive of hearing of it—I can read—I have read an account of this in the newspapers—I read the newspapers between my first and se
cond
examination—I did not read any account of where the money was kept.

Q. On your oath, did you not read in the newspapers where the money was placed? A. I have read the papers, but I speak from the words Gould named to me, that the money was in the drawer—I have no recol
lection of reading in the papers where the money was placed.
COURT. Q. What did you read the newspapers for, was it to refresh your memory? A. No.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Was it a Sunday paper you read? A. I have read the "Dispatch" once, but not the whole of it—I think I read it the Sunday after my first examination—I do not know that I did—I am not certain that it was the Sunday after, because in our business I catch hold of a paper, and lay it down again—I did not read the whole account of the evidence—I had not the opportunity of doing so—I might read part of it—I recollected about the drawer after I had been to Hatton-garden on the Saturday.
COURT. Q. Had you mentioned about the drawer till you read the "Dispatch?" A. No.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How old are you? A. Twenty-seven—the last time I lodged at Allen's is about seven weeks back—I left Allen's to go to the situation I am now in—I was lodging there last Christmas, and Gould lodged in the same house—he did not lodge there at Christmas—he was at place—he had been at place a week or two, at Mr. Bartlett's, the Barns
bury Castle public-house—I was living there alone at Christmas—I knew Mr. Templeman's cottage, and the window, but never took particular notice of it—I cannot say whether it was a whole window, or whether there was any thing the matter with it.

Q. Were you aware that in the conversation you say took place a rob
bery was intended? A. Yes—I understood his intent was to commit a robbery—it was mentioned only in my bearing—I did not suppose any violence was to be done to the old gentleman—I understood him to mean by "a right one," somebody to assist him, that he could depend upon—I understood there was to be a robbery only.

Q. Were you shocked at it? A. Why, I took very little notice of it—I named it to Squires when I went round at nine o'clock, and said I did not know whether it was intended or not—Squires lives at the Two Brewers public-house, the next house—I did not name it to any police
man—Squires said he did not think if he had any intention he would have named it—Squires is not here.

Q. Did you think it was a joke? A. I did not think he was joking—I took no notice of what he said, till I named it to Squires at nine o'clock, and neither of us took notice of it—it never entered my mind till I read—till I heard of the murder.

Q. Why name it to Squires if you thought nothing about it, and if you did think any thing about it why did you not name it to a policeman? A. I named it to Squires, and it did not enter my mind afterwards till Squires told me he had read in the paper of a murder, and I read of it when I got home—I first heard of it on the Wednesday—Squires had read the paper, and named it to me—I do not know James Rogers.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have been asked about a cash-box—had some charge been made against you about it? A. Yes—only suspicion—I think I was in custody a week—I was afterwards discharged by the Ma
gistrate
—I did not come to trial upon it—except on that occasion I have never been in custody in my life, and I never bad any charge of dishonesty theft of any kind made against me.

Q. Did you give evidence in this case of your own accord, or were you called on to do so? A. I had not time to come over—I sent word over to Mr. Allen on the Wednesday, about an hour after Squires made the communication to me—I went before the Magistrate on the Saturday—one of the officers called on me—that was after I had made the communi
cation to Allen—I stated at the office all of the circumstances as near as I could recollect—I never had any quarrel with the prisoner—I had always been on friendly terms with him—Squires is living at this place now—(a messenger was here sent to fetch Squires.)

JOHN RICHARD JOHNSON . I live at No. 7, Dotset-street, Spitalfields, and am a print-colourer—I colour caricatures, and principally religious prints—that is the way in which I get my living—I have known the pri
soner between four and five years—I saw him on Friday evening the 13th of March—I left off work about half-past seven o'clock that evening, and when I came down stairs there was a person in the passage inquiring for Jem—I did not see him—I heard him, and when I came down in the passage the woman below said Jem was not at home, and then I saw the prisoner "Arthur Nicholson"—that was the name he gave me—"a private in the 11th Light Dragoons, Canterbury"—the prisoner was present when I wrote this paper I have in my hand—that if ever he should be tried as a deserter, I might know his right name—he gave me this, as near as possible, twelve months ago last December—he desired me to write down his name that I might know if he was ever tried as a deserter, he was the man—it is my handwriting—he saw me write it—I put it into the drawer, and there it remained till this occurrence took place—when I saw him in the passage, I said, "Dick, how do you get on?"—he said he wanted to see Jem—I asked him what he wanted to see Jem for—he said he wanted to see him, for he wanted to borrow a screw—I asked him what for—he said he was going to serve an old gentleman in a lonely cottage—I told him he had better not do any thing of the kind, if he did he would be sure to get trans
ported—he told me he might as well be transported for that, for if he was takes as a deserter, he was sure to be transported—at the end of that con
versation, a fight took place at the bottom of our street, and I and the pri
soner went down together to see it—seven or eight rounds were fought—the police came up to disperse the mob, and I and the prisoner returned back again about as far as our door, and I wished him good night—he said, "You had better not go yet, for I want to see Jem very particularly"—I asked him what he wanted to see Jem so very particularly for—he said he wanted a darkey, that he had left there some time ago, and it might be handy—I told him if he wanted to see Jem so very particularly, he had better go over the way to the public-house—he said he could not go over the way, for he had no money—he further stated, that if he served the old gentleman, as was his intention on the Saturday, he was going over the water to see his aunt or cousin, and would give me a call on Sunday, and let me know.

Q. Let you know what? A. Whether he had robbed the old gentle
man, I suppose—that is the inference I drew from what he said—he did not say he would rob him—he said he would call on Sunday and let me know.
Q. You have said he spoke about a screw and a darkey, what is meant

by a screw? A. I cannot tell, only from what I have been in the habit of reading—I have read "Bell's Life in London"—I know what screw means according to the defamation I have heard in the book—according to the defamation I have read in "Bell's Life in London," it means a picklock-key—I bid the prisoner good night, and we parted—I saw no more of him—I afterwards saw an account of the murder at Islington in the newspaper, and the day after I gave information to a policeman of the H division—that division is in the neighbourhood of Spitalfields—I then stated what I have to-day, I believe, word for word—I was examined before the Magistrate, after recognising the prisoner—I was taken by a policeman to be sure of him—Waddingtoo the jailer said, "You are to recognise the prisoner"—I believe I said "Yes," and I pointed to him, and said, "That is the man."

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known Gould? A. Between four and five years—that was as near as possible my first acquaintance with him—I only knew him then as Dick or Richard, nothing further—that was at Mr. Webber's, at the public-house at the corner of our street—I never inquired his other name—I should say I knew him three years as Dick.

Q. Where was be living when he got you to write this card? A. Why, I gave him a lodging, to tell you the truth, at Now 7, Dorset-street—I have not known him up to the present time—he has been absent some time—I have not seen him but once previous to the Friday, for eight or nine weeks—that was at the Weaver's Arms public house—Jem is a party who had moved in below me—his name is James Rogers—he had moved in very likely two months—it is not my house—I am only the tenant of one apartment—I have known Rogers, I should say, fourteen or fifteen years—it was not by my introduction that he came into the room below—if I had had the letting of the house, I would not have let him in at all.

Q. You knew him too well? A. No, I never knew any dishonest action of the man—he is a labouring man—he has only a small apart
ment at 1s. 3d. a week—he gets his living among the wharfs, on board the barges, to carry flour or corn, or any thing on shore if barges come up, and if they wanted any body to unload them, they would as life employ him as any body—he may have regular masters for any thing I know—I do not know that he has.

Q. What has he been during the fourteen or fifteen years you have known him? A. He got his living by going about buying and repairing old umbrellas, portering, or any thing like that—I do not know whether he comes in at good hours at night—he never lived in the same house as me before—I had no objection to having him in the same house, but I have not the letting of the house.

Q. Why should you object to let him the house if you had the letting of it? A. Because he is a man so often out of work, and could not afford to pay his rent—I have been in business about twenty-four or twenty-five years, not always colouring religious prints, but latterly I have done them—I have done some thousands of prints for Mr. Fairburn, No. 110, Mino
ries, principally religious prints—I have occasionally done maps, plans, and charts—that is the only trade I have been in—I never kept a shop—I have been eleven years in my present lodging—I have a wife and family living with me—I have three children out of eight—they live as well as they can since my work has been stopped—my work has been stopped since this fatal occurrence—I have had one little job since.

Q. Why could you not colour prints notwithstanding this? A. On account of my giving evidence—it got into the newspapers, and my master stopped the work—I suspect so—I do not buy and sell things at all—I never did to my knowledge—I bought this coat the other day, and I might sell it to-morrow—I bought every thing I have got on.
COURT. Q. Do not answer in that foolish way—did you ever buy and sell to make profit? A. Never.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You never bought anything? A. No, it was never said that I did—I was never charged with buying any thing—I was never in any scrape about a robbery, I am certain—I will tell you, the prisoner and I were together at a public-house, a man charged me with robbing him of a shilling, and the prisoner went with me to the station-house, and offered the man 5s. to let me out—I was not let out—the man came between one and two o'clock in the morning, said he had found the shilling, and wanted the man to discharge me, but he said he could not, as the charge for felony was signed—the man never appeared afterwards—it happened at the Bluecoat Boy public-house, in Dorset-street, within a door or two of my own house—the man was a butcher—I have known him in the neighbourhood for years—that is not quite two years ago, I think—I was once locked up for being drunk and disorderly—I have never been in any difficulty about other people's property, except about the shilling.

Q. When the prisoner said he was going to commit a robbery, did you endeavour to persuade him not to do so? A. I said if he did he would be sure to be transported—I did not endeavour to persuade him not to do it—I did not believe him—I understood what he meant by a screw, by reading "Tom and Jerry" and "Bell's Life"—I have seen that expres
sion in "Tom and Jerry" many times—I have borrowed the book once or twice.
Q. If you thought he really meant nothing, how came you to tell him he would be transported if he did it? A. Why he would if he did it.
Q. I thought you considered he was in fun? A. I did not think he was in much fun—I did not think he was in earnest—he has laughed and joked with me many times before.
Q. Did you really think him in fun or earnest? A. I should firmly believe now that he did mean it, but I did not believe he meant it at the moment—I should sooner say he was in joke than in earnest.
Q. Why persuade him not to do it, then, and tell him he would be transported? A. I said if he did it he would be transported.

Q. Now, while you were pausing to give me an answer, did not you hear what that gentleman (MR. Ballantine) said—did you not give me your answer after hearing what that gentleman said? A. I did not hear what he said, I did not hear him speak—I could see his lips go, that is all—I did not shake hands with the prisoner when I parted with him—I have shook hands with him many times—I did not see Jem that night, nor tell him he was wanted—I left the prisoner at the door when I bid him good night—I did not go up to my own room—I came back between eleven and twelve o'clock, I believe—I do not know whether Jem was at home—I did not see Jem at all before I read any thing in the newspapers—he was in the back-room, I suppose—we have to go down the cellar into the yard, and there is the back-room there—I saw Jem once before I read the newspaper—I think he came home as usual.
MR. JONES. Q. Had you any other reason for not liking to have Jem in the house except his poverty? A. That is all—I have never been in custody except on the occasion I have mentioned.

Q. You have been asked whether you believed the prisoner was serious when he said he was going to commit a robbery; did you believe it at the time? A. So many jokes have passed between me and him, I did not know how to take it—I believe it now, from what has happened.

COURT. Q. What time was it he came to you? A. About twenty minutes to eight o'clock, as near as possible—at half-past seven o'clock I sent my wife home with three hundred prints—I had just got my coat and shoes on and came down, and judge it to be that time—he was with me altogether about a quarter of an hour—he left me before eight o'clock—as I passed the station-house to go into Church-street, the bells struck out eight, that was the moment I had parted with him—I did not see Jem during all the time I was with him.

JAMES ROGERS . I live at No. 7, Dorset-street, Spitalfields—I am an umbrella maker by trade, but I do not follow it—I work at the water-side as a labourer—I have known the prisoner about five years, or it may be six, by the name of Richard or Dick—on the 13th of March was the last time I saw him, barring seeing him at Hatton-garden—I saw him at my door, where I live, when I was going home between eight and nine o'clock in the evening.
COURT. Q. Between eight and nine o'clock? A. Yes—I believe I once said a quarter before eight o'clock—I now say it was between eight and nine.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where were you standing? A. I was coming home, and he was standing by the window as I was coming, just between the window and the door—the first observation he made to me was, "Jem, you are just the chap I want to see"—I said, "What do you want to see me for?"—he said, "I want for you to lend me two screws and a darkey"—I should say he meant skeleton keys and a dark lantern—I said he might as well ask me for a £500 note as to ask me for such things as them—nothing else was said on that subject—I said I had no money for beer or else I would treat him, and he said he had none—my brother-in-law was along with me—he had not been with me all the time—he came up along with me when I came to the door, but I don't think he heard any thing of what he said, but I cannot say whether he did or not—I said to my brother-in-law, "Bill, you stand a pot of beer"—he said, "I have not got any money without going home to fetch it, but go over to the public-house, call for a pot of beer, and I will come and pay for it"—we went to the Blue-coat Boy public house in Dorset-street, and had a pot of beer; my brother-in-law paid for it—I once kept an old iron shop—that was while I was acquainted with the prisoner, and he knew it.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was it you kept the old iron shop? A. In Little Paternoster-row—I did not keep the house—I had the lower part nine or ten months, then necessity compelled me to leave it—I sold locks and any thing in that way—I bought and sold old iron, and sometimes bottles and rags, not any thing that came to hand, because there might be things that came in a different sort of way—I was very careful of what I bought—I used to go and collect things—I mostly bought in Petticoat-lane—I have never been in any scrape arising from the old iron shop, not at all—I was never taken up—if I were to say I never was in any prison, I should say false—when I was a boy I got a month for sleeping out in the open air—

that is seventeen or eighteen years ago—I was in no business then—I was sent to Coldbath-fields for a month—I cannot recollect any thing else—I be
came acquainted with the expressions darkey and screws by reading "Bell's Life" newspaper—I don't know whether Johnson reads it—I am sure I have seen those expressions in "Bell's Life"—I never read it in "Tom and Jerry"—I do not know that I ever took up that paper—I have known Johnson, I suppose, about ten years—he lodges in the same house as me, with his wife—he has got three or four children I believe—I very seldom go up into his room—I believe he was a print-colourer when I first knew him—I may have been up in his room two or three times.

Q. How long before Gould visited you had you seen Johnson? A. I suppose not for a month—I go in and out of the place—I live down stairs—I have not lodged there altogether, I believe, above four months—I have seen Johnson out of the house, but not above once in the house to my knowledge—my brother-in-law's name is William Crane—I found the prisoner standing between the window and the door—Crane was with me—he went home to get the money, returned and paid for the beer, and then retired to look after a sweetheart of his—he was standing within a yard or two till he went away to get the money—the prisoner did not whisper—he spoke loud enough—Crane might or might not hear it—I cannot say—I dare say he might—I had no notion what the darkey and screws were wanted for—I never gave it a thought—there had been no darkey left with me—I did not see Johnson at all that night—I do not think I saw him at all after, till I had been up to Hatton-garden—I am not positive of it—he and I had no conversation—I never kept such things as skeleton keys when I was in the iron trade—nothing of the kind, nor darkeys—when I first knew the prisoner he was pot-boy at a house at the bottom of the street.

Q. Did you think there was any thing wrong in asking for these? A. I did not give it a thought whether there was any thing wrong or right—I did not trouble my head about it—I passed it by as a joke—I get my bread by the water-side when I am in employ—I do not work for any body in the umbrella business—I work for myself, but I am an occasional man in the other job—I had a job on Saturday—I sometimes go out very soon in the morning, and work from eight or ten o'clock in the evening till twelve o'clock, when we are landing ale, and such things—I was examined at the police-office.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were you compelled to go before the Magistrate, or did you give evidence voluntarily? A. I saw it in the paper, and I went up to Hatton-garden the same day, but there was no Court then—it was not the same day I saw the account of the murder, but the same day I saw my name in the paper—that was on Monday, and I went up the same day, but the examination was not on—it took place the next day, and I attended and gave evidence—I stated all I knew—I have been on friendly terms with the prisoner, but I have not seen him above twice for two years.

COURT. Q. When you went to be examined you knew Johnson had been examined? A. I was told he had been the week previous, but I did not see Johnson till after I had been examined—I think I saw his ex
amination in the newspaper before I was examined, but I will not be positive.
RICHARD SQUIRES . I am waiter at the Two Brewers public-house, George-street, Horsemonger-lane, and have been so four years. I know

the prisoner, but no more than by seeing him three times in my life—I saw him last, I think, on the 17th of March—he came over the water to see Wright—it was on the Thursday evening, to the best of my recollection—I cannot swear whether it was Thursday or Friday—it was about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, or it might be nine o'clock—I saw him close by where Wright lives, at the Duchess of Kent public-house—he was not with Wright at that time—I know Wright by seeing him, and drinking with him now and then—we drank together that evening, me, Wright, and Gould—I left first, I believe, but the other two went away directly—I went home.

COURT. Q. And went to bed? A. After I had done my business—I had to wait on the company in the tap-room—I did nothing more—I saw Wright again, I believe, that night, at the Duchess of Kent public-house, where he lives.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Had you any conversation with Wright when you saw him again, if you did see him? A. I do not know whether it was the same evening or next morning, it might be next morning he saw me, and we might stop and ask how we got on, and he brought it up about Dick—he mentioned Dick's name.

COURT. Q. Who came for you to-day? A. I do not know his name—he said I was wanted here—he did not mention for what, to my know
ledge—he did not tell me what I was wanted for—he said I must come to the Old Bailey, or something of that sort—he said he wanted me along with him—he did not say what about, nothing at all.

Q. Do you mean to swear you had no idea what you were gong to be examined to before you went into that box? A. Yes, I knew what it was—I was up at Hatton-garden before, but my evidence was of no use—I was not examined—I stated what I knew, and it was of no use.

Cross-examined. Q. You stated what you had got to say, and then you were sent away? A. Yes—I came here to-day in a cab, with one of the servants, I expect, from this office—he found me at the Two Brewers pub
lic-house—I had very little conversation with him in our way—I have not seen Wright here to-day—I heard him examined at Hatton-garden the last time—he and I have talked about the matter since—we have sat together and talked—I was at Hatton-garden the last time he was there, on Tuesday, a week ago—I had never been there before—when I went up I found Gould standing near the Duchess of Kent public-house—Wright was not there then—he came up about half a minute alter I met Gould—I cannot say what was said while we were talking together, nothing very particular—we drank a pint of porter, or whether it was a pint or a pot, I cannot say—we drank it at the opposite corner to the Duchess of Kent, where Wright lives—I mean outside the Duchess of Kent—we were about three minutes to
gether there, it might be four—we did not talk much—we continued drink
ing till the pot was out—no one paid for the beer at that time—we had beer out with us from my house and from the Duchess of Kent—I was carrying beer out—I cannot say whether the pot was taken out of my beer or out of Wright's—we must have paid for it when we went home—I paid say mis
tress for mine—I cannot say how much was drank—I cannot say whether it was a pint or a pot—I cannot swear whether it was my master's beer, or Wright's master's, that we drank—I might have paid my mistress for it—I paid for all I brought out—I cannot say how much I paid her—no money was pro
duced by any body while we were drinking—nothing was said about money,
to my knowledge—I believe, when I saw Wright he was coming along with his porter—I was talking with Gould.

Q. When they saw each other, did they ask each other how they did, or what was said? A. No, it appeared they had been together before—Wright might have said, "Halloo"—I do not know that he did—I cannot recol
lect any thing that was said—it might have been half-past eight or nine o'clock—I should say it was half-past eight o'clock, as near as I can recol
lect, because I was out with my porter—I go out with it at eight o'clock, and I was just going home—I might have some porter left—I generally have—I cannot say whether I had or not.

Q. Did you toss for any porter? A. We might have tossed, I do not recollect tossing—we might have been a pint each, or stood a pint, either one of us—I have no recollection whether we tossed, or whether we were a pint each, or whether one of us was a pint—I cannot say we did not toss—we might have tossed, and I forget it—I immediately went in, and was waiting on the customers after that—I came out again that night—I might come out with beer after that—that would be at nine o'clock, if it was half-past eight before—if it was after nine o'clock I did not come out—I do not sleep in the house—I sleep with my wife, in St. George's-court, Dover-road—it might be twelve o'clock when I went home—I cannot recollect when I went home that night—I cannot recollect who I saw when I was going home.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You were taking out beer for your mistress—what is the method? do you account for the number of pots you take out? A. I have to pay for all the porter I take out every day—I never return any—I pay for all every night—the person who came to me this morning did not produce any thing, but had a cab for me to ride over—I live 200 or 300 yards from the public-house I work at—I cannot swear whether I left that night before or after the house was closed.

CHARLES ALLEN . I live at Wilson's Cottage, Pocock's-fields: I am a boot and shoemaker—I have seen Mr. Templeman's house since his death, but not before—I know it now—I should say it is between 300 and 500 yards from where I live—I have known the prisoner, as near as I can tell, about twelve months—he has lodged at my house several times—I cannot possibly state when he commenced lodging with me the last time—he lodged with me at least seven nights before this occurred—I know he had very little money, if any, before the 16th of March; and I was confident, from circumstances which occurred, that he had no money—when he has come home of an evening he has said he had no money; and I considered by his getting up of a morning, and not having breakfast before he went out, that he had none, for few people like to go out without food, if they have money to purchase it—on the Saturday night before this occurred he had none, because he made an observation when he came into the house that he had no money, but he should have some in the course of to-morrow, which was Sunday—on the Monday morning following that Saturday, I think he went out between eight and nine o'clock—he had no breakfast with us before he went out that morning—I believe he was dressed some
thing similar to what he is now, but I cannot positively swear whether he had that coat or a jacket on—as far as I can tell, I believe he was dressed much as he is now—he had on a pair of shoes, which I made—I did not make them for him—they were misfits, but I sold them to him—they were ancle-shoes, similar to what I have on now, shoes the lea
ther of which comes above the ancle—they had nails—I saw Gould

nailing them about a fortnight before—they were then getting the worse or wear, still they were wearable—I had seen them everyday on his feet—at the time I saw him nailing them they were fit for wear, I am certain, and would have lasted much longer for nice fine weather than for wet—I have no recollection whether he went out alone or in company that morning—I have no recollection of seeing any body before he went out—the next time I saw him was, as near as I can tell, on the Tuesday morning about three o'clock—I was then lying in my own bed, and my wife likewise—he came into the house—it was very light at the time, the moon shining—it was the lightness of the moon—the instant he came into the house he went into his bed-room, as the door opens into the room—he opens his bed-room door and closes the front door while he passes to his bed-room—my wife said to him, "Richard, it is early," or "late," I am not sure which, and his reply was, "It is early"—nothing more passed—the next time I saw him was, I believe, between eight and nine o'clock on the Tuesday morning—we have no clock to judge the time, but as near as I can tell I saw him between eight and nine—I got up between six and seven—he got up between eight and nine—I was in my sitting room—he came into it, passed through, and went to the wash-house—the wash-house leads to the privy and to the back-yard—he remained in the wash-house, as near as I can tell, from twenty five minutes to half-an-hour—when he came out of his bed-room he had his coat and waistcoat on his arm, and I believe his boots in his hand, but I am not certain whether they were on his feet or in his hand—when he returned, he came through the room where I was sitting at breakfast, and went out at the front door—he went straight from the wash-house to the front door and went out—I observed nothing particular about him when he went out—I believe he had on the same clothes he has now—he had on the same shoes as I had made him, but they were blacked—when he was in a situation he blacked them every morning, but not at other times—how he got the brushes to clean them I do not know, but the brushes were in the back place when he was gone—they were my brushes and blacking—if he used it, it was my blacking.

Q. Can you tell whether, on this night, he used any candle or rush-light to go to bed? A. I never saw Richard have a candle in our house all the time he was in it, unless he asked for such a thing, and that was very seldom—if he wanted one it was merely for a minute to get something out of the room, and he was supplied by our candle which stood on the table—I have not found any candle or rush-light about my premises since that night—he returned about a quarter past seven o'clock on the Tuesday evening, much about that time—I had heard of the murder about half-past ten, or near eleven o'clock—when the prisoner came home I was gone to fetch a pint of por
ter and a rasher of bacon for supper—when I returned he was sitting in my room talking to my wife—the conversation when I came into the house was, I believe; on the subject of the murder—the first time, I believe, I spoke, or Richard spoke to me, was, "It is a shocking thing: do you consider he could not have done it himself?"—the reply I made was, "Richard, how could it be possible for persons to do such things themselves, having their hands tied and their eyes blindfolded; is it likely?"—that is all the con
versation I remember between Richard and me, till afterwards—he was sitting at the table a few minutes after, then got up and went into the back place—he went through the wash-house, as if he was going to the privy—he said his inside was out of order, and he went out at the door as if

going to the privy—he did not remain there more than six or seven minutes—I mentioned to my wife a circumstance which had occurred, and when he came back and sat down I was eating some bacon on a piece of bread—I cut off a piece of bacon—it fell on my knee, and went a contrary way to him—I then cut another piece, and it went towards his legs—I did it pur
posely, to satisfy myself of something I thought concerning him, that he had got a new pair of shoes—I had a suspicion that he knew some
thing about it—then I did a thing which I have no doubt he under
stood, I took the candle off the table, and put it between his legs—he directly put up his legs and hid his shoes behind the legs of the chair, and then began the conversation—he said he had been over the water to see his cousin, who had a pair of shoes which did not fit him, and he had jumped into them—before that, he said he should like to have something to eat, and asked if I would go and fetch him a slice of bacon and a pot of beer—I said, "Richard, why not go yourself and fetch it?"—he said, "You know I don't want to go out"—I knew that there was an assault warrant out against him—I fetched him a slice of bacon, a pot of beer, and half-an-ounce of tobacco—he gave me 1s. to pay for it—he said he had been over to Clapham, Limehouse, Blackwall, and that way, and called on hit cousins and aunts, and they had given him some money—he did not say how much—after I had fetched the beer we had some conversation respecting the preceding night, what a shocking, dread
ful affair it was, how any body could have committed such a horrible crime—it was no more than common conversation respecting the murder—the con
versation took place chiefly with my wife—I did not pay attention, my at
tendon was engaged at that time—I recollect asking Richard how it was he was so late—he said he had been to Mr. Frimley's till twelve o'clock, and when he came from there he lit on some friends who detained him—I should say he was in bed before nine o'clock on Tuesday night, or about that time—when he had gone to bed, in consequence of suspicions I entertained, I bolted him in—I did not give information at all—the policemen came at eleven o'clock that night, as near as I can tell, and took him—I had at one time a cheese-knife in my possession, which I have since found—I had also a piece of wood in my possession—I believe it was plum-tree or damson, rather better than a foot and a half long, and about two and a I half inches wide, with sharp edges, and flat—it was very smooth—the edges were sharp—it was to set seams with—it is a heavy wood—I used it in my business.

Q. Have you told us all the conversation, as far as you recollect, that took place between you and the prisoner on the subject of the murder? A. As far as happened, except part that my wife was speaking to him—there was a conversation on Scripture—I recollect in one part Richard said, if the ten commandments were just, or the Mosaic law was right, he had broken them all, for adultery he had committed many times, and drunken
ness—and then that conversation dropped with me, and went on with my wife—I got up to go into the yard—that was at the time we were talking of the murder—it was all in the same conversation—I saw some money produced in a stocking at the station-house at Islington—neither the money or the stocking was my property—I believe one farthing was all the money in the house at all that day—I have never been in the habit of keeping money in the wash-house or privy—we have not had any to do it.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you present during all the time your wife

was in conversation with the prisoner that evening? A. Certainly not—I went to fetch some beer, therefore I could not—I went to fetch the beer and bacon after he came home—it was not his bacon I cut when I disco
vered his shoes, it was my own bacon—I did that while the prisoner was sitting at the table, before I went to fetch his bacon—I believe I ate my own supper before I fetched his.

Q. At that time had there been any conversation about the murder? A. The conversation might have been about the murder, but I took very little notice of any of the conversation, therefore am not bound to answer the question.

Q. Now I ask you to answer the question, had any conversation taken place about the murder before, as you say, you cut the bacon, and saw his new shoes? A. I have already answered that the conversation when I entered the house was on that subject, but I paid so little attention to the conversation between my wife and the prisoner, that probably I could not utter fifty words of the conversation the whole evening, unless the prisoner spoke to me—I mean, I could not utter fifty words of the conversation between the prisoner and my wife, except I had the leading point to lead to it, named—there was a good deal of conversation between him and my wife—I had some suspicion at the time I discovered the new shoes—I cannot say whether it was after that that I went and fetched the bacon for the prisoner—I believe I had eaten my own supper before I fetched it, but I will not swear it—I am not confident whether the bacon was cooked before or after.

Q. At the time you went out to fetch the bacon, had you any suspicion as you have stated? A. Certainly I had at the time, and before—I had before he came into the house—I fetched it from a person of the name of——I cannot recollect—it was about a hundred yards off—I was absent about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—on my return I found the prisoner sitting at the table in conversation with my wife—as soon as his bacon was cooked he had his supper, smoked his pipe, and went to bed—when I bolted him in his bed-room I said, "He is in, he shall never come out any snore by me"—if my face had been towards him I think he may have heard that, but my back being to
