ber, Charles King came to my house between eight and nine o'clock—I had a lodger named Lewis, who was an acquaintance of Charles King—I was at that time confined to my house with a broken bone—I remained in the room while Charles King and Lewis were breakfasting—they entered into conversation, and I heard Charles King, say to Lewis, "There is a 50l. chaunt for that job at Porter's, in Lincoln's Inn-fields"—I also heard, from a question that Lewis put to King, that they had sold some plate at Child's, in Goswell-street-road—I did not hear any more particular con
versation about that—King came again on the Saturday morning, and said he did not know what he should do or where he should go to—Lewis advised him to go to Boulogne—King said he had to meet Chapple in the Dials, to arrange where to go to—I will not be exact about the Chris
tian name he used, but it was Chapple—King left my house then—I saw him again on the following Tuesday, at this end of London-bridge; but on Monday, the 16th of September, a twopenny post letter came to Lewis, by the last post in the evening—Lewis asked me to read it to him—it was from Charles Chapple to Lewis—I read it to Lewis, and afterwards burned it—in consequence of what I observed in that letter, I went, for the purpose of apprehending Charles Chapple and Charles King on the Tuesday—on my arrival at London-bridge I saw Charles Chapple and Charles King—(I did not know Chapple at that time)—they were together—I do not know whether they came in a cab—they bad carpet bags, and were both dressed in Macintoshes—my lodger, Lewis, was with them—I gave in
formation to the policeman on duty, but they escaped—there is no doubt but Lewis told them I was there.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What are you? A. A shoe-maker—I have not worked at it for about eight months, and then I did not work in general at the business, but for my friends or children—I

have a small income derived from a relation—I do not keep a lodging-house—I never did, no more than one or two lodgers—there may have been three at times—I may have had two lodgers besides my father—there may be two or three of a family in one room, but there has been but one tenant—I have had a man and his wife and seven children.

Q. Had you known Charles King before? A. Never in my life—I had seen him once at my house on the day before I beard this conversation, but then only for a moment—he was a perfect stranger—he said this, at once before me and Lewis—he might have said it from Lewis being my lodger—I thought it was a curious subject—such a thing never happened to me in my life, before nor since—I was once secretary to a loan society—I was never charged with any thing—I have a little income by which I have supported myself and my wife since this prosecution, with my wife's work—I have received money from many people—I have received my own money, which I have coming in every month—I have not earned money by any calling or office—when I have lost a day's work in looking after the prisoner Charles King, Mr. Porter has though proper to pay me for it, bat I do not consider that earning.
COURT. Q. Have you been paid regularly by Mr. Porter? A. No—I could not tell how much I have received from him—I have not received 10l.—I may have received 5l.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. And you are here as a witness with 5l. of his money in your pocket? A. No, I have not—I have spent more than Mr. Porter gave me—I never made any charge upon him—I never received any thing for a day—it is a month ago, and more than that, since Mr. porter paid me any—I cannot tell when I first appeared before the Magi
strate—I think it was on the 21st of March—it was on the 17th of Sep
tember that I first took any step with regard to this robbery—it was not by the day that Mr. Porter paid me—he probably made me a present of a few shillings—I went with Mr. Porter to Gravesend on the day we lost the prisoners—I cannot say when I first received any money—it might be the latter end of September or October—I have not been working at any trade since 1833—I will not swear that I may not have had 8l. of Mr. Porter—I do not know whether I put it down in a book—I put down no money in a book that I received from Mr. Porter.

Q. Why did you swear you did not know whether you put it down? A. What has that to do with this robbery?—I never put them in a book, and I do not believe I have received 8l. from Mr. Porter—it has been 5s. or 6s. at a time—it is impossible for me to say how much—it has been a great many days during the last eight months.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You were employed by Mr. Porter to look after King? A. I was not employed, but I gave him information, and he thought proper to make me a remuneration—I was, on and off, for about six months looking after King—I went to Gravesend and other places—the largest sum I ever received was about three half-crowns, but not for one day.

JOHN PORTER . re-examined. I did not know any thing whatever about Charles King till I received communication from Thomas James—I never paid him any money for evidence—he knew King, and he went down to Gravesend, which the officers knew—I gave him sometimes half-a-crown, and sometimes other sums, what I thought might be his outlay—perhaps, in all, about 7l.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you keep any book of it? A. I did at first—I am not aware that I have given money to any one else—I may have given Pocock, the officer, some silver to reimburse him—I gave him 5s. on one occasion—the officer came to me, and I took two half-crowns out of my pocket and gave him—he had incurred expenses—he went to search a house, and there was a cab to pay for—I may have given the other witnesses money to pay their expenses—I gave Selina Kemp 3s. or 4s.—I think Black had half-a-crown for his expenses—I think I paid Collier, as he had been put to expense—I do not recollect how much I gave him—I have not made up the account—I do not know that I put it on paper—I have not put the sums together—I could not tell how much I paid Collier—he went down to Reading, I think, and he wanted expenses.
COURT. Q. Have you given him 3l. or 4l.? A. Yes, more than that, should say 10l.—it was for reimbursing the expenses—I could not state the amount—I have been put to considerable expense.

Cross-examined by MR. LUCAS. Q. Will you state, as a man of honour, whether any of the witnesses, and which, if any, have a prospect of receiv
ing money after this trial? A. None whatever; and what I have paid them, has, I believe, been much less than they have actually laid out.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you been in practice as a solici
tor? A. Ten years—on my solemn oath, I have not furnished money to any witness for any thing more than for their expenses on my account, and their loss of time—I was very unwilling to let them have a farthing.

MARY JAMES . On Saturday morning, the 14th of September, when Charles King came to my husband's house, I opened the door to him—Charles King was in company with Lewis, our lodger, and my husband—I did not remain in the room all the time with them—they went out—I went out to look for a lodging, and in the meantime they came back—it was between one and two o'clock—I told Charles King I had seen a lodg
ing—he went with me to look at it—we did not see the lodging—the per
son was not at home, and Charles King declined seeing another lodging, saying his time was short, as he had to meet a friend of his in Seven Dials at five o'clock—he said he was sorry he had not procured one before, as he knew they were after him and another, for a robbery in Lincoln's Inn
fields.

SELINA KEMP . I am in the service of a clergyman at Paddington—I know Henry Cox—Sophia Cox was living with him—Sophia Cox is a sister of Charles Chapple. On Monday, the 9th of September, Sophia Cox came to my lodging in Chapel-street, Tottenham-court-road, about three o'clock in the afternoon—she had a brown paper parcel with her—I asked what was in it—she said, "Some shirts for Charles Chapple"—we went out together to her lodging in Southampton-court—as we were going, she said Charles King and Charles Chapple had done the robbery on Saturday night—I remained at Sophia's lodging to tea, and then I left her—I saw her again a few days after, and then she told me that on the night the rob
bery was done, she was very badly off, and when she came home she be
gan to scold Charles Chapple and Henry Cox, and Henry Cox said to her, "Hold your noise, here is a sovereign for you"—that Charles Chapple said, "Hold your noise, see what I have done—I have done it at last," and he held out his hand, and had something in it, but she did not see what it was—she said she told them, while she was cross and scolding them, that they were not half thieves enough—on the following Wednes
day

I called on her again, and went to fetch something for her—I think that was on the 22nd of September—Thomas Chapple came in, and be and Sophia Cox both looked very much confuted—she said to him, "Will you have any thing to drink?"—he said, "Yes"—I went and got sixpenny-worth of gin—when I came in with it, Sophia Cox told me to go over to her father's to fetch her brother George—I went, and he came back with me—he went in, and I met Sophia Cox at the door—the did not seem to wish for my company, and I wished her good night—I saw that Henry Cox was in the room as I went away—from that time I did not hear any thing more about the robbery till Thomas Chapple was taken into custody, which was on the Friday after—after that Sophia Cox told me she had 5l. of the money—that Henry Cox had 5l., and that Charles Chapple and Charles King were gone to Dublin because they were fright
ened for fear they should be taken up—I was taken up about three weeks or a month after, when I was in Sophia Cox's apartment—Henry Cox was with me—I sent to my parents, and expressed a desire to say what I knew about the matter—while in custody I was in the same place where Sophia Cox was—when we were remanded, she told me not to say any thing, and she would give me two sovereigns—the said she hoped her fa
ther would get off, for Charles Chapple's money was hid on Mr. Semple's wharf—(I think he is a timber-merchant, I am not certain)—her father's name is Charles Chapple—he is the prisoner—the Charles Chapple I have been speaking of, is the son, who is not here—Sophia Cox said she wished they, (the policemen) had not taken the coat, as that was the coat that Charles Chapple had on when he did the robbery—she is not the wife of Henry Cox—she told me so—when I was in custody, and was brought up, Henry Cox used to tell me not to say any thing, and I should be sure to get off—Henry Cox and Sophia Cox were in bed together one morning when I was there, and a strange man came in—Henry Cox said to that man, "MRS. King has got Charles King's money, and I should like to go and take it from her, for I dare say it is somewhere about the house."

COURT. Q. What have you been in the habit of calling Mrs. Cox? A. I used to call her Sophy—I used to represent her to other people as Cox's wife when I spoke of her—she told me herself a good bit ago that she was not his wife, and her sister told me so likewise—I am now in ser
vice myself.

Q. How came you not to make any communication to your parents when you found the persons with whom you were intimate were a gang of thieves? A. Because my relations would not speak to me—they had turned their backs on me—I was not in service at that time.

Henry Cox. Q. Will you have the kindness to tell how it was you were first with us? A. Doing some needle-work that I never got paid for—I turned Sophia Cox's silk dress—I never walked the Quadrant in Regent-street till Sophia Cox's sister took me there—I was not ill when I first came to your place—I should not have been in trouble but for you.
Henry Cox. When she left us she took several articles of wearing apparel away from my wife, and she was afraid of being taken for them.

COURT. Q. You say Sophia Cox's sister took you into the street—what is her name? A. Eliza Chapple—she took me down the Quadrant first; but now my friends have enabled me to get a service, and I am living in service very comfortably—it was owing to my getting to those bad habits that my friends turned their backs on me.

Sophia Cox. You stole a bundle of things of mine, and you said you would do for me—you said you would not mind lying a month for me—I took you when you had robbed your lodging in Pitt-street, Tottenham-court-road—I let you stay a few days till you could get the money—you said you would send me out of the country, and owned you had got my things—you made the bonnet dirty, and sent it to be cleaned.

COURT. Q. Did you ever take a bundle of her things? A. No—she gave me a bundle; I did not steal it—I never lived in Pitt-street—I asked her one day to lend me a bonnet, and I dirtied it and sent it to be cleaned, and when she can pay for it she shall have it.

WILLIAM MAGRATH . I live in Nelson-place, New-road, and am a plumber. I knew Mr. James of Little Cumming-street—I was there on the 12th or 13th of September, about four o'clock in the afternoon—I went into the front parlour to wait for James, and after I had waited a little time, Lewis, who lodged there, (I do not know his Christian, name,) I think it is William,) and Charles King came in—Charles King produced a watch and asked Lewis to wind it up for him—Lewis asked him what he had given for it—King said he had taken it out of pledge for 18s. or a pound, and he would have kept the gold watch, but Chapple made him sell it with the plate—I was looking through the parlour window, and thinking the conversation rather strange, I paid more attention than I should have done—Lewis asked King what were the amounts of the notes—King said, "Tens and hundreds," and that they had received between 200 and 300l. for them—I then turned round and said, "Gentlemen, you have got a good booty or prize, where did they come from?"—Charles King said, "From the lawyer's in the fields"—they did not stop above five or six minutes—James was at that time ill in bed—when the others were gone, he came down, and I told him the moment he came down—on the Tues
day following James came to me, and in consequence of what he told me, I went with him to London-bridge, to apprehend Charles King—I know the hotel at the foot of the bridge—after waiting some time I saw a cab drive to the foot of London-bridge, and just at the moment I saw King and another young man close to the cab, but I cannot say that I saw them get out of it—there is a way out of the hotel which leads to the water-side, and I lost sight of them—I afterwards went with Mr. James to Mr. Porter's to tell what I knew.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you known King before? A. I never saw him before—Lewis was in the room—I have been a plumber and glazier all my life—I lodged at James's about three years ago—I went there that day about some glass I had to repair for him—I had known Lewis before, but not Charles King.

WILLIAM LEIGH WOOD (City police-constable, No. 410.) I was on duty at London-bridge on the 17th of September—James and Magrath applied to me to take some persons into custody, but I searched, and found nobody—I saw a number of persons about, but none that I can identify, except the prisoner Charles King—I had seen him and another person pass in a very hurried manner, within two minutes of the time I was spoken to—they had carpet bags with them, and Macintoshes on, and were going to
wards the steamer.

GEORGE COLLIER (police-sergeant E 38.) On the 29th of September I went in company with Pocock to the lodging of Ann King, in Frederick-street, Portland-town—I believe she is the mother of Charles King—I

found her in the front parlour—I told her she was suspected of being con
cerned in Mr. Porter's robbery, at No. 22, Lincoln's Inn-fields—the said she knew nothing about it—I asked if she had got any money—she said, no, she had not got any—I asked when she had seen her son Charles last—she said, "About a fortnight ago"—I asked if she knew where he was—she said, "No"—I searched the room, and while I was doing so she walked to the door several times, and endeavoured to go out—I pulled her back, and told her I could not allow her to go out—I found no money nor property relating to Mr. Porter's robbery—I then asked if she had got any money about her—she said, "No, not a farthing"—I asked her to show me her pocket—she pulled out some papers—I said that would not do for me—I felt, and there was something hard—I told her to take her pocket off, and she gave it me—I found in it fifty-one sovereigns and 23s. in silver—I asked whose that was, and where she got it—she said, "From Eliza Plant," and at that moment Pocock, who had left the room, brought Eliza Plant in in custody—I told her that Mrs. King said she had received that money from her—Eliza Plant said, "Yes, I brought it up, and gave it her; I received it from Charles King"—I told Ann King I should take her on suspicion of the robbery—she said, "If right takes place, others will suffer for it as well as me"—(Plant cohabits with Charles King—I afterward caught them in bed in Nottingham-place, Seven-dials)—I went to Southampton-court, where I found Sophia Cox, Henry Cox, and Selina Kemp—I found a coat there, and in a drawer in the wash-hand stand I found a life-protector—I asked Henry Cox whose coat that was hanging behind the door—he said it was his—I said I should take it—Sophia Cox looked at me, was very much confused, and asked what I wanted to take that coat for—I said I thought I knew a person who had worn it on a cer
tain day, and I should take it—I then took them to the station-house—on the 5th of October I went to Brook-street, New-road, where Charles Chapple lives—he was not at home, but came in directly—I asked if he had got any money—he put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out a bag, containing half-a-sovereign and 3s. 6d. in silver—I asked if that was all he had got; he said it was—I then searched him, and in his trowsers pocket I found five sovereigns wrapped in this piece of green baize—I asked him if they were his; he said, no, it was his master's, Mr. Semple, of Camden-town, and he had received it for a bill for him yesterday—(there is a Mr. Semple keeps a timber yard, and Charles Chapple worked there)—I said he must go with me to Mr. Semple's to know if he had received it for a bill for him—he then said, "Oh dear, it is no use telling a lie about it; I picked it up in the Park yesterday, I found it"—I said he must go with me on suspicion of being concerned in Mr. Porter's robbery—I put him into a cab, and he said, "I have been drawn into it"—I asked him when he had seen his son Charles—he said, "About a month ago"—I asked if he knew where he was—he said. "No"—I had been in search of Charles King ever since September, and took him on the 21st of February, in bed with Plant, at No. 21, Nottingham-place, Seven-dials—I told him to get up—he got his trowsers, and I said I should search them—he said, "No, I shall put them on"—I said, "It is no use"—I took them, and in the pocket was this bag, with four skeleton keys in it, which he put into my band—I looked about the room, and found a bundle of sixteen skeleton keys on the coals in the cupboard—I took Thomas Chapple in the same house where his father was, on the 21st of February.

SUSAN FROST . I know Mrs. Ann King. In September last she was living in my house—Eliza Plant and Charles King were living together at my house—Ann King came to lodge with me on the 5th of September—Charlas King helped her to move in on that day.

T. CHAPPLE—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

C. KING—
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Fifteen Years.

C. CHAPPLE, PLANT, A. KING, H. COX, S. COX—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: First Jury, Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1282.
THOMAS LEE was indicted
for assaulting
Emma Boyle.

GUILTY . Aged 55.—
Confined Two Months.—Penitentiary.

1283.
MARY SMITH was indicted
for an assault.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.

1284.
JANE WATFORD was indicted
for concealing the birth of a child.

GUILTY. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined One Year in the Penitentiary.

p.hi: Third Jury, Before Mr. Baron Alderson.

div1.p:
1285.
CATHERINE MICHAEL was indicted
for the wilful murder of
George Michael: she was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the like offence.

SARAH STEVENS . I am the wife of john stevens, and live at No. 22, Praed-street, Paddington. I know the prisoner—I received her child into my care nearly nine months before its death—it was a fortnight and a few days old when it came to me—it died on the 31st of March, or Wed
nesday morning, the 1st of April—it was very well on the Friday before its death.

Q. Had it been poorly before that time? A. Not lately—on the Friday before it died, in consequence of a letter I received, I went to the prisoner, who was living at Mrs. Kelly's, No. 49, Hunter-street, Brunswick-square, as wet nurse—I saw the servant first—the prisoner came down stairs to me, and asked me how I was, and how the child was—(the child's name was George Michael)—I said the child was very well—she asked me to walk into the parlour, which I did, and she said she had an old frock for the baby, and a bottle of medicine—she gave me a bottle which was full—this looks like the bottle—(looking at one)—it was tied down with a bit or paper inside the cork, and a piece of white paper outside round the bottle, and sealed with wax—the paper was not fastened on the bottle—the cork was tied round—the paper was wrapped round the bottle—I could not see what was in it till I got home—when she gave it me she said it would do the baby's bowels good—I said the baby was very well, and did not want medicine—she said it had done her mistress's baby good, and it would do her baby good—she said I was to give it one tea-spoon full every night—

she said if any thing happened to the child I waft to let her knew directly—I do not recollect that she said any thing more—she said I might expect a doctor on Monday next, about five o'clock—I rather think she laid Dr. Reid, but I am not certain of the name—this was on Friday, the 27th of March. The prisoner paid me for taking, care of the child—she gave me 7s. a week for the first five months, I believe, and then I spoke about falling it to 6s. a week—I lowered it to 6s. a week for one month, and then I fell it to 5s.—that waft the rate when the child died—the doc
tor did not call on the Monday—when I got home I took both papers off the bottle—I did not open the cork—the contents looked dark, something of a treacle colour—I never took out the cork—I took off the paper directly, to see if there were any directions—I never gave the child any of the contents of the bottle—I stood it on the mantelpiece directly, where it continued till the Tuesday, not intending to give it to it at all—I keep the house, but other people lodge in it—on the Tuesday afternoon I left the room at half-past four o'clock—there was myself, my daughter, who is eleven years old, the baby, my little William, who is five years old, and Richard, my son, who is three years old, in the room up to that time—those were all the persona in the room—about half-past four o'clock I was called out of the room—the baby was very well indeed then—all the persons I have named were in the room then—I could not say whether the bottle was on the mantel-piece at that time, but it had been there all that day—I had cleared the mantel-piece about eleven o'clock, and it was there then—I did not remove it afterwards, nor any body else to the best of my knowledge—when I saw it at eleven o'clock it was in the same state, as to the contents, as when I received it—I kept it for fear the doctor should come—I thought, in consequence of what she said, a doctor might come, and I meant to ask him how I should give it—when I went out of the room at half-past four o'clock I left the baby sitting on the floor, playing with my chil
dren—it was awake and lively at that time—at six o'clock I went into my parlour—I was in the kitchen, and I heard Richard cry—I thought he had fallen, and went up into the parlour—I found the baby then lying on the sofa asleep—I went and took him up in my arms, and his hands Were clenched—I could not open his fingers—I spoke to him, and endea
voured to rouse him—I said, "George, George"—he looked up, and closed his eyes again, aft if he was going to Sleep—I told my girl to go and fetch a pennyworth of castor oil, and gave the child half of it—he then went fast asleep—I looked at the mantel-piece directly I came in—the bottle was on it, and half the stuff gone—I sent my girl for a doctor, and called up a midwife who had been with me at a labour in the house—the medical man who came first was Mr. Sellick, assistant to Mr. Philpot—they looked at the child, and asked me what I had been giving him—I told them I had given him castor oil, but my little boy said something.

Q. Was the attention of Mr. Sellick, ox Mr. Philpot called to the half-empty bottle? A. When I came into the room, I took the bottle in my hand, and smashed the stuff into the fire in my passion—this was after my little boy had made a statement—I went to the bottle to see whether he had done it—I smashed the stuff on the fire Before Mr. Sellick came—there was nothing to show him but the bottle—I had done nothing else to it—I had not rinced it—there was a good many drops in it When they came—I told Mr. Sellick and Mr. Philpot what my little boy had told me

—MR. Sellick took the bottle with him—he brought something and gave the child directly, and ordered hot water and things for it—I gave the things they advised—they ordered it medicine and a hot bath—I did every thing in my power—he seemed in convulsions, but quite asleep—he never awoke up all night—he died about twenty minutes before five on Wednes
day morning—I sent Mary Batty for the prisoner about nine or half-past nine o'clock on Tuesday night—she came—I said, "Look what trouble I am in"—she said she could not help of it—I drew her attention to the child—she went and looked at it—I told her what my child had told me—she came and sat down by me, looking, at the child, which was on another person's knee, who lived up-stairs—I said the child was very bad, and told her my little boy had given it the medicine out of the bottle—I asked her if the doctor had given it to her, and she said, "Yes"—I sent for Mr. Philpot while she was there—he asked her where she got it—she said the doctor near there, or something of that sort, I cannot exactly say what.

Q. Did she say where she got it from? A. She said something about round the corner—she stopped about a quarter of an hour—she came again next morning, about ten o'clock—the child had been dead some hours then—I asked her to go into the other room and see it—at first she objected—she never made no notice—she said, "No," but after a little while her cousin, Esther Jones, who lives near me, said, "Go, Kate, and see the child"—she then rose up, and went with me and her cousin into the room—she looked at the child—she said, "It is better off," or something like that—she did not say she was very sorry—MR. Philpot was not sent for that morning—she went out, and said she was going to Mr. Philpot's house—nothing had been said about him—she was absent about a quarter of an hour—MR. Philpot lives about two minutes' walk from me—when she came back, I asked her if she had seen Mr. Philpot—she said, "Yes"—I asked her if it was all right, if she had had the medicine from the doctor—she said, "Yes"—I asked her whether it was doctor Reid—she told me, "Yes"—I did not ask her any thing else—she said nothing else—she stopped from ten till two o'clock that day—I did not see her again till she was brought to our house by a policeman, on the Saturday night—when she gave me the bottle, she told me to give it one teaspoonful of the stuff every night.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How many children have you? A. Eight—I have had eight nurse children before—when they have required medicine I administered it—I am acquainted with the ordinary dis
eases which children are subject to—I have never given laudanum for dis
eases of children—I have never known it to be given or seen it given to chil
dren in my life—I have seen it given to ladies in drops when I have been with them—I have never given it to ladies—I have had a pennyworth for the tooth-ache, often enough to know the colour of laudanum—I do not think I should know the smell of it—I do not think I have taken it above twice for the tooth-ache—I can swear I do not know the smell of it—I do not think I should know the taste of it, although I have taken it for the tooth-ache—I have just put it with a feather to my tooth, that is all—I could not see the cork of the bottle when it was delivered to me—it was tied down with a white piece of paper outside—there was a little piece of paper inside—I will not be sure whether it was white, or what colour—the seal was out
side on the cork, with the white paper—the string was round the neck of the bottle over the white paper inside and not outside—it was coloured pa
per

inside, but I could not tell what colour, as it was nine o'clock at night—the white paper was fastened with red sealing-wax outside, which I was obliged to break to open the paper—it was sealed on one end, which re
tained the ends of the outside white paper over the cork—I found a piece of paper tied over the cork inside, folded up very neatly—the child was in very good health when I had it—it had not been otherwise for a month or five weeks—I had complained to its mother about its bowels—the last time was about a month or five weeks before this—she did not give money to get the child medicine then—she did when it was about two months old—she then gave me 5s. to get medicine, and 5s. she made me a present of—the was at that time paying me 7s. a week for nursing the child—I received 10s. from her on that occasion—she came there and gave it to me—I had complain
ed of the child's state of health then—it had been very ill some time—I bought some stuff from Mr. Philpot's assistant—I took it there two or three times—I paid 10d. one day, and I think 14d. another day, that left 3s. out of the 5s. but I think I had some powders at the same time, and some castor-oil, in addition to the medicine from Mr. Philpot's shop—I was not served by Mr. Sellick—I bought them myself—I had two pennyworth of castor-oil once or twice, and I was always giving him something at that time—I took him down to Ramsgate for change of air—I did not take any of my own children down to Ramsgate—I paid for it—this was the only occasion on which I received money from the prisoner for medicine—I never received 4s. from her—I am quite certain that is all the money I received—when I got home I took the paper off the bottle, expecting to find directions how to give the medicine to the child—I put the bottle on the mantel-piece over the fire-place, which is rather low—it is above the fire-place—it is rather a low mantel-piece.
COURT. Q. I suppose your boy could reach the mantel-piece? A. He must stand on a chair to reach it.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was there a fire on this day? A. Yes, and a fender before it—I have frequently seen my child stand on a chair—when I came into the room my little boy was sitting down by the fire-place—the child was lying on the sofa asleep at the time—the child five years old is not here—the prisoner came on the Tuesday night, and also on Wednesday morning—I asked her to go in and see the child—she said, "No"—there can be no mistake at all in that—I am certain she said that, and that only—I am certain she did not say, "I am very sorry"—if she had said so I could not avoid recollecting it—I have not a very good memory—I will undertake to swear what the prisoner said to me when she gave me the bottle—there was nothing at that particular moment to fix it on my mind—I will under
take to say the words without any mistake—she asked bow I was when I came to the door—she said, "Here is an old frock and a bottle of medi
cine for the baby"—she said, "Give my baby one lea-spoonful every night"—I said he was very well, and did not want medicine—she said the doctor would most likely call on me on Monday, and she thought she had better apprise me of it—she gave no further directions as to taking the medicine.

COURT. Q. What was the doctor to call on you on Monday for? A. To see the baby, about five o'clock, and I waited till the doctor called before I would give the child any thing—I was not waiting for the doctor's directions particularly—I meant to ask him how it was to be taken if he came—I am not sure she did not tell me to ask for the doctor's directions—she said the doctor would most likely come to see the baby at five o'clock.

Q. Are you quite certain she did not say you were to wait for the doc
tor's directions before you gave it? A. No.

MR. RYLAND. Q. With the exception of the castor oil you gave the the child the night it died, did you ever give it any medicine except under the direction of a medical man? A. Never, except a little powder I got myself—at one time it had other medicine—at one time, when first I had it, she sent me four powders—I could not be certain whether she sent them with the clothes, or whether the nurse at the hospital gave them me—I gave it one of them—the child was very ill at the time, and it did it good.

COURT. Q. At the time she told you to give the child the teaspoon-ful of this every night, did she tell you you were to give it a teaspoonful partly of this medicine and partly of water? A. No—she only said a tea-spoonful every night—I did not give it to the baby because I did not think it wanted medicine—I expected to have directions on the bottle how to give it, whether in water, tea, milk, gruel, or any thing, but I did not think of giving it to the child at all—I never kept medicine on the mantel-piece—I did not know I had poison in the house—she mentioned something about steel medicine to Mr. Philpot, not to me.

JANE STEVENS . I am going on for twelve years of age—I go to church sometimes, and say ray prayers and catechism—I know it is wrong to tell a lie—God knows whether I tell lies or not—he will punish me if I do so when I die—I am afraid of that—(sworn.) I am the daughter of Sarah Stevens—I knew the little baby George—my mother left me in charge of it the afternoon before it died—she left my two brothers and the baby and me in the room—after my mother had been gone out some time I went out for a loaf—I left the baby sitting down in a corner awake and very well, and my two brothers in the room—I was gone about ten minutes—the baby was sitting in the same place when 1 returned—my brother Billy said something to me when I went in, and in consequence of that, a little while after I looked upon the mantel-piece—I bad seen a bottle on the mantel-piece before I went out for the loaf—it was such a bottle as the one pro
duced—I had seen it about a quarter of an hour before I went out for the loaf—it was on the mantel-piece then, and was full then—when I looked at it on the mantel-piece after what Billy said, it was half full—it was in the same place—I took up the baby and it fell on my shoulder and went to sleep—I sat up till about twelve o'clock—it did not awake up to that time.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was Billy when you came in? A. He was just by the baby—he was playing with it, patting his hands—I had not been out more than ten minutes—the baby was just in the corner, just by the mantel-piece, on a little carpet on the floor.
COURT. Q. Billy was very fond of the baby, I suppose? A. Yes—I did not smell Billy's lips, nor the other boy's.

MARY BATTY . I am single—I am a dress-maker, and live in Praed-street, Paddington. I know Mrs. Stevens and her children, and the baby which she had to nurse—on the night of its death I was sent for to Mrs. Stevens's—I went about nine o'clock, and saw the baby—it was very ill—I went for the prisoner by Mrs. Stevens's request—I did not see her first—I did afterwards—MRS. Stevens had told me to ask her to come and see the baby—I told her she must come and see her baby, as it was very ill
indeed—she said she would ask leave to go—she went for the purpose of asking leave, and went with me to Mrs. Stevens's house—I did not go into the room with her.

RICHARD GODFREY SELLICK . I am assistant to Mr. Philpot, a surgeon near Praed-street, Paddington. I was sent for to Mrs. Stevens's on Tuesday evening, the 31st of March—I got there about five o'clock, or it might be a quarter before—I saw an infant there—I examined it—it was perfectly insen
sible—I smelt its breath, and could perceive the odour of laudanum—this bottle was shown to me—I examined it—there were a few drops more than there is in it now—it is pure laudanum I should say, from the smell and taste of it, and from what I see here—it is such as they sell in the shops for laudanum—the state of the child was such as might be produced by taking laudanum.

Q. What quantity of laudanum administered in that state would produce the effect you found? A. One drop has been known to do it—it is never safe to administer one drop to a child—one drop would not produce the effect I found, but one drop has been known to poison a child—a tea-spoonful would—about sixty drops is an ordinary teaspoonful—that if rather a large dose—this bottle would contain about an ounce—half of it would be about half an ounce—a teaspoonful administered to an infant nine months old, such a baby as I saw, would be certain to destroy life—I gave it some medicine—castor oil would not be likely to do harm nor good unless it acted as an emetic—if it had, it might have done good—mustard and water would have been better—it appeared a hopeless case from my first seeing it—I first saw the prisoner on Wednesday morning—she came to Mr. Philpot when I was there, and said, "My poor little one is dead"—she asked if I was the gentleman who had seen the child—I told her yes—she said she was sorry to lose the child when it had attained that age—she then asked if there was likely to be an inquest—I said in all proba
bility there would be an inquest, and asked her whether she had inquired into the mistake—(I had heard people talking about one medicine having been given for another)—she said yes, she had been to Dr. Reid's, and that Dr. Reid had told her it was his young man's mistake—she said the young man had given it in mistake for another mixture off the counter—I then left her.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the bottle precisely in the same stole in which it was handed to you? A. Yes—it has rather evaporated—there might have been two or three more drops than there is now—there is now very likely one drop—there was about three times as much as there is now—the Coroner tested it—it has been very trifingly diminished by him.

Q. Are you able clearly to say that the mixture which is in this bottle has not been adulterated? A. I cannot say that for certain—if adultera
ted by water, whatever quantity was given would certainly produce less effect.
Q. If laudanum has been in a pure state in a bottle, and afterwards mixed with water, would the spirit remain, or would it amalgamate? A. It would if shaken together.

FREDERICK PHILPOT . I am a surgeon, and live in Upper Southwicstreet, Paddington. On the evening of the 31st of March I went to Mrs. Ste
vens's house—I found my assistant there, and saw an infant which I ex
amined—it was in a state of complete insensibility in a woman's lap in the room—it could not be roused—the pupils of the eyes were contracted—I

smelt its breath, but could not detect clearly at that time the odour of lau
danum—the child had had two or three emetics given it before I saw it, but they had not operated—the stomach was insensible to all emetics—I attribute the state the child was in to a strong narcotic—laudanum would produce the effect I saw—every thing was done that could be done for it—I was shown this bottle, and examined it—there was a small quantity of laudanum in it—there was enough to enable me to form a judgment of it—I am convinced it is laudanum—one or two drops would be sufficient to destroy the life of a child in health—a tea spoonful would be quite suffi
cient—I afterwards made a post mortem examination—I found all the symptoms of poison by laudanum, by opium—I attribute its death to opium, laudanum—I have not the least hesitation in saying the child died by taking laudanum, from the symptoms during life, and the appearances after death—the prisoner came to the house in the course of the evening—I saw her—she said she was the mother of the child—I told her the child was labouring under the effects of laudanum—she asked me if I thought it would recover—I told her I thought it could not even live many hours—I then asked her respecting the medicine, and who had tent it to her—after some hesitation she told me that Mr. Reid, of Bloomsbury-square, had sent it to her—I asked her for what purpose Mr. Reid had sent the medicine, and if she knew the nature of it—she stated that it was some preparation of steel, and was intended to remove some offensive discharges from the bowels—I merely expressed my surprise that a medical man should send out that quantity of laudanum without a label, and shortly after left, leaving her there—about ten or between ten and eleven o'clock next morn
ing, she came to our house, and told me her little boy was dead—I said it was an unfortunate occurrence—she said she had seen Mr. Reid—(she had stated on the over night that as the went home she would call on Mr. Reid to inquire into the mistake)—I asked her how he accounted to her for the mistake—she stated that Mr. Reid regretted the circumstance, and that he said it was a mistake of his young man's; that the laudanum was intended for another patient of his, a lady who was in the habit of taking it, and could not sleep at night—she owned then that it was laudanum—she ex
pressed her regret at losing the child, after having reared it to that age at her own expense'—I asked her if her mistress was aware of the circum
stance, I thought she had better acquaint her mistress with the fact, as in all probability there would be an inquest, and her attendance would be required.

JAMES REID . I am a physician. I live in Bloomsbury-square—I know the prisoner—she was confined in Queen Charlotte's lying-in hospital last year—I procured her the situation of wet nurse in the family of Mr. Kelly—I never furnished her with any medicine for her child in March—none was furnished by my house to my knowledge—she did not call at my house on Tuesday evening the 31st of March to my knowledge—I did not see her at all—on Wednesday evening the 1st of April, a little after five o'clock, I found her waiting in my room, and asked if she had come with a message from Mrs. Kelly, who is a patient of mine—she said she did not, that she had a favour to ask me—(I had not then heard of the death of the child)—as she hesitated very much I inquired what it was—she then said that her child was dead, that a coroner's inquest would likely be held upon it, and that she wished me particularly to attend the inquest—I in
quired if the child had met with an accident—she said it had—I men
tioned

that as I was not conversant with the facts of the case, my attend
ance would be of no use, but I would attend if I was summoned—she then hesitated good deal, and stated that it was not at her own request exactly that she wished me to attend, that the child had had laudanum given to it by a child in mistake, and that the medical man who had seen the child said it would be necessary for me to attend—she made use of the expression, "If I am hanged for it, I could not support the child on my wages"—I then asked her the circumstances of the accident—she said she bad sent some laudanum in a bottle to be given to the child, and that it had neither label nor direction upon it—recollecting she had mentioned that a child had given it laudanum, I said to her, "But of course you directed what quantity should be given, or was to be given"—she replied that she had directed a teaspoonful to be given at night—I then told her I was exceed
ingly sorry I had asked her the last question, and still more sorry that she had answered it, that if I was summoned on the coroner's inquest I should be on my oath, and should have to repeat the whole conversation—I advised her to say no more to me on the subject—I felt it my duty to communicate what I had learnt to Mr. Kelly, and she was dismissed from their service—she came to me on the Friday to inform me that she had been dismissed by Mr. Kelly, and to ask me if I had heard any thing about the coroner's inquest, and that, if there was to be none, would I intercede with Mr. Kelly to take her back again—nothing more passed then—on the Saturday even
ing I saw her again—she came to consult me professionally on the state of her milk—I gave her advice, and she then asked me if I had heard of the coroner's inquest—I had found a summons on my table the moment before to attend the inquest—I had just come in—I showed her the summons, and told her so—she asked me if she might call the next morning to in
quire the result—I told her I should be happy to give her any professional advice, but on the other part of the subject I had rather she would inquire up at Paddington.

Cross-examined. Q. You state you are a physician, do you dispense medicines? A. I do not at present—I formerly did—I did not at this pe
riod—the prisoner was very seldom in the habit of being at my house about her mistress—she knew the house well.

COURT. Q. She knew that you did not dispense medicines probably? A. No, I think she did not—I was formerly a general practitioner, and she did not know that I had changed—I have made use of my diploma lately—I have had it many years—I have put "Dr. Reid" on my door now—be
fore it was Mr. Reid—I did that on the second of April—the plate was off on the Tuesday.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You have told us a remarkable expression, that if she was hanged she could not support her child on her wages, were those the exact words she used? A. Yes—I feel some doubt as to the precise time at which she made use of that expression—I had not told her it was a very serious affair, or any thing of that kind.
COURT. Did that expression make any serious impression on your mind? A. It certainly startled me at the time.

Q. Was the expression merely, "I will be hanged if I can support it on my wages?" A. No—I am quite certain her words were—"If I am hanged"—the expression was so inapplicable to the previous conversation, I could not understand it myself—I went on talking to her—it was not till she had named a teaspoonful of laudanum that I began to suspect.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do I understand you have no doubt the expres
sion was used before she mentioned the teaspoonful? A. Yes, I have no doubt of that—I am quite sure it was before she said she bad sent some laudanum in a bottle—I did not ask her whether the bottle had any label or direction—she seemed rather anxious to impress upon me that there was no label on it—I had recommended her to Mr. Kelly's family—I had a good opinion of her as a wet-nurse—I knew very little of her, except having been servant in another family—I believe she was seduced.

COURT. Q. You select wet-nurses from their physical qualities? A. Unless I know any thing of their moral character—I believe the common people administer laudanum very rashly—there is a great consumption of opium among the lower classes in London—they deal very rashly with that drug—the same as ardent spirits, they give it to children, and to children of a certain age it is poison, if they give a certain quantity.

WILLIAM JONES . I am a chemist and druggist, and live at No. 34, Tavistock-place, Russell-square—I know the prisoner—I have often seen her in my shop—she came to my shop one afternoon about the middle of March—she was alone—she purchased three articles, one was laudanum, the other acidulated drops, and the third I do not recollect—she had a small square bottle of laudanum—this bottle is very similar to it—it was the same size as this—she asked if I was in the habit of selling laudanum—I said, "I do sometimes spare it, but I always require to know for whom it is, and for what purpose"—she said her mistress, Mrs. Kelly, had de
sired her to ask if I would spare a small quantity, a shilling bottle—I said, "I suppose I must not refuse Mrs. Kelly"—I knew Mrs. Kelly—I did not ask her for what purpose it was—she said her mistress was in the habit of taking it, being a bad sleeper—I put two labels on the bottle, "lauda
num," "poison"—it was wrapped up in a piece of paper like this—(produc
ing a bottle)—I am not certain whether it was sealed or tied—the cork was secured like this—when I gave it her I begged her to give it into the hands of Mrs. Kelly, and desire her to keep it under her own care—it was pure laudanum—I heard of the death of the child between Tuesday and Wednesday, at the end of March—I did not see the prisoner at all on Tuesday, the last day of March, nor on Wednesday, the first of April—she never stated any thing to me about any accident happening by means of the boy—I never advised her what quantity would be proper to give to any person.

Cross-examined. Q. You have not a bottle folded up as the one you gave the prisoner on the outside? A. No—a person unaccustomed to the trade cannot fold up bottles—it is not a common habit with me to seal them—I very rarely seal them—I do sometimes, certainly—sealing would confine the ends of the paper.

Q. Do you think a person not in your business could fold up a bottle in that manner, and seal the ends in the way you send it out? A. They could a bottle which had been previously wrapped up, they could wrap it up in the same paper, and seal it—it would not be so neatly folded—the labels were fastened on with gum.
FREDERICK FESTUS KELLY . I hold a situation in the Post-office, and reside in Hunter-street—the prisoner was in my service as wet-nurse.

JOHN MORTIMER BOWIE . I am a medical student. In March last, and the beginning of April, I resided in the house of Dr. Reid, as his boarder, not as an assistant—he had no pupils or assistant in the house

besides myself—I saw the prisoner at his house on Saturday—I did not see her there on the Tuesday before the Saturday—I never supplied her with any medicine at Dr. Reid's—she never complained to me of any mis
take made in delivering medicine to her.

p.rs: GUILTY. (Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury, conceiving there were some extenuating circumstances in the case, being seduced and thrown on the world.)—

p.hi: First Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1286.
CHARLES DUNECLIFT was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

WILLIAM PEDDER . I keep a book-stall, in Carnaby-street, Golden-square. Some time ago I was indebted 1l. 13s. to a person named Scott, for which I received a summons—I attended the Court of Requests, at Westminster, and was ordered to pay the sum in four weeks, with 3s. costs—I went to the Court, I think, on the 28th of November, to pay the money, and saw the prisoner in the Court, opposite the place where the money ought to be paid in, where they call people's names over—I was looking about, and the prisoner said to me, "What is your business?"—I said I had come to pay in some money which I was sued for by Mr. Scott—I had the order with me, and showed it him—he said, "It is all right, I can take your money; it will be perfectly light"—I had not known him be
fore, nor did I employ him—I understood him that he could take my money for the Court—I firmly believe he said, he was an officer of the Court—he said he could take my money, and it would be perfectly right—he said he had not got a pen and ink there, but if I would walk with him over the way, he would take my money and give me a receipt for it—I went over the way with him, and paid him the money, because I believed him, from his own words, to be a lawful officer of the Court to receive the money—I paid it under no other impression—I paid him 1l. 13s. for the debt, and 8s. for the costs—he gave me this receipt on a card—(read)—"Received the debt and costs due to Mr. Scott, of the Gas Company, 1l. 16s. Charles Duneclift. Nov. 28"—when he gave me this card, with this receipt on it into my hand, I said, "Now, sir, is this perfectly right?"—he said it was perfectly right, and I should never hear any more of it—on the 9th of March a distress was put into my house for the same debt, and 8s. more costs, and I had to pay it twice over—I never taw nor heard any more of the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you go to the Court after
wards? A. No, he did not point out at all the place where the money was to be paid—I was never summoned in my life before.

CHRISTOPHER CUFF . I am the chief clerk of the Westminster Court of Requests. I am the proper person to receive money paid into Court there—there is no other person authorised to receive money—the prisoner had no authority to receive money, or to act in any way—an order was issued for William Pedder to pay the debt and costs, and it was not paid in—there are two orders up in the Court against agents receiving money.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1287.
ALBERT BAHN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

JOHN GEORGE SMITH . I keep an eating-house in High-street, Wapping. On the 26th of August the prisoner came to lodge at my house—I never knew him before—he represented himself as a ship-chandler, that he had taken a warehouse, and said he should be a permanent lodger for many years, he hoped—he was to pay me 15s. a week for board and lodging—he has not paid me one farthing, and he is my debtor for 75l., as a loan—I had a Spanish certificate from a debtor named Newton, who bad been engaged in the Spanish war—I got another certificate from Mr. Clark, of the Spanish Commission, in exchange for it—the one I got from Mr. Newton was for 27s. 6s. 5d.—it was a transfer similar to one I hold in my hand—I was in September last showing the document to a friend—the prisoner was at my house at the time my friend called—there was something stirring respecting this certificate—he thought there would be some interest likely to be paid—the prisoner said, "Have you got a Spanish bond, Mr. Smith?"—I said, "I have a transfer, or certificate, as they call it"—he said, "I should like to see it"—I said, "I can let you see it"—after my friend was gone I showed it to the prisoner—he said, (giving it me back again,) "If you like I will take it to my banker's to ascertain the value of it for you, as it may be useful to you at any time"—he said Messrs. Coutts in the Strand were his bankers—I told him I did not want money just then, nor want to part with it, but I said, "Whatever you do, do not take any thing on it"—I gave it to him again, and cautioned him not to make any thing on it—I would not take 19s. 11d. in the pound, because it would be paid some day, but he might inquire the day price on it if he liked—he took it, and said he should be going up to his banker's in the course of the day, and he would inquire—he afterwards said that if I liked, if I doubted it, he would give me cash for it—I said, "No, my own document is what I want"—he said, any time I wanted 100l. or 1000l. I should have it, that he had 2000l. standing at his banker's—I was out when he came home—I did not come home till the evening, and did not see him that night—I believed him to be a respectable person—I never asked him for his board and lodging up to that time, but I have latterly—two or three days after I gave him the certificate I said, "Respecting that transfer that I gave you to ascertain the value of, you have not given it me again"—he said, "Oh dear, I did not see my banker, he was not within, but at any time you shall have it"—we were to go to his banker's, but we could not go then—he said, "If you are afraid I will give you the cash"—I said, no, I wanted my own pro
perty—he said, "I will go and inquire about it"—(I have never had it since)—I went with him to Coutts's about a month after the transaction—he said he was going up Leadenhetll-street, and asked me to take a walk with him—I went, and he went up and spoke to one of the clerks at Coutts's—I thought it was on business—that made me contented, thinking my document was safe at Coutts's—he was not apprehended on my pre
mises—he was taken on another charge.

Prisoner. Q. Did you give me the certificate, or did your wife hand it over to me? A. I did—I know a gentleman named Miller—I have not seen him in this Court—I never offered him this bond to raise 20l. on—I gave it you to ascertain the value, and bring it me back—I sent my wife to two of my relations to borrow money on my own account—I never in
tended to raise 20l. on this bond.
COURT. Q. Did you give him this bond, or allow him to have it in, order to raise any money on it? A. No, by no means.

Prisoner. Q. Did you, in presence of your wife, request me to raise money on it, or not? A. No—I have asked you for it a score of times—I did not want 30l. for this, and 20l. more to send over prohibited machi
nery—I went with you to Calais for a week's recreation—I did not take machinery there—you did not pay my bill to get me out of a bad House there—I did not tell you not to tell my wife—I took 10l. to Francs—you paid one days' expenses, and I the other—I swear that I never offered this Spanish certificate to any one to raise money, and never showed it to any one but you—I solemnly swear I gave you this certificate to ascertain the value of it—I never gave it you for security for 30l.—you did not pay 15l. 10s. 6d. for me—I know nothing about any machinery—I let you have 20l. in gold, because I thought you were a respectable man, and you gave me the keys of his warehouse for security till the deeds were drawn up, with a prospect of going into partnership—I did not give a bond for security of 30l.—I did not tell you to keep it—I never inquired the market price—I trusted you with it, and to this present moment you did not offer it back if I paid you 30l.—you did not offer to give it me back on payment of 8l.—a stranger called on me, and said if I would pay 8l. the certificate should be forthcoming—no one called on me to induce me to bring this present charge.

SAMUEL CLARK . In April, 1889, I was employed as accountant in Mr. Black's office. I produce, a copy of the original document, which I got by desire of the prosecutor—it is for wages due—they are properly called Spanish certificates—I have heard them called Spanish bonds.

JOHN BLENKINSOP . I am in the service of Counts and Co., and have been so twenty-six years-storing that time we never had such a name as the prisoner's in our books—we had no account with him in April, or any time—I have examined the books for years.
Prisoner. Q. If a person presented a cheque at your house, it would not take above five minutes? A. That depends on the nature of the cheque.

GEORGE SIMMONDS . I receive an annuity from government, and live in Richmond-buildings, Soho-square. I have known the prisoner seven or eight months—I met him in the City on the 1st or 2nd of January—he said he had purchased a Spanish bond for 27l.—that he was short of money, and should part with it again—he offered it we for a sum of money, but I do not recollect the amount—I did not purchase it.

Prisoner's Defence. I solemnly declare the bond was given to me as security for the payment of 30l.—the prosecutor stated before the Magis
trate that he was not in want of money, and be now says he tent his wife to borrow some.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1288.
JACOB ISAACS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1289.
PATRICK ROACH was indicted
for a common assault.
GUILTY .

1290.
PATRICK ROACH was again indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of April, 2 coats, value 6l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l.; 1 hat, value 10s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 6s.; the goods of
Michael Doherty.

MICHAEL DOHERTY . I live in Bell-alley. I had the articles stated, in my box, I broke the key of it a fortnight or three weeks before the 6th of April, and I gave the articles stated, in charge of the prisoner's wife, who lived in the same house—I missed the trowsers, the coats, and other things—they are now here—the pawnbroker has them.

JOSEPH JOHN GOODE . I am a a pawnbroker. I have two coats and a pair of trowsers, which I took in of the prisoner on the 6th of April, which he said were his own property—it was between four and six o'clock.

Prisoner's Defence. I pawned them; I went out that morning at six o'clock to work; the prosecutor took my wife and made her drunk; and when I came home I found him and my wife in the act of adultery. I went to the fire, took up the poker, and gave him a pretty good share of it. I went out, and when I returned I asked my wife for some money; the prosecutor said I might take some clothes, and make money, which I did.; and in the evening he got sorry about letting me have them; he asked me for the money, and the money was scattered between them.

MICHAEL DOHERTT
re-examined. I did not permit him to pledge them, I did not know he had them.

GUILTY . Aged 63.—
Confined Three Months.

1291.
ROBERT WALKER, alias Smith,
and
JOHN RUFFETT, alias Smith,
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of February, 1 work-box, value 1l., the goods of
Mary Ann Parker: and 2 pillow-cases, value 5s.; 4 yards of muslin, value 14s.; and 1 napkin, value 1s.; the goods of
William Henry Parker.

ANN PARKER . I am the wife of William Henry Parker, and live at Plais
tow with my brother, Thomas Gethin. I have a daughter named Mary Ann, who is fifteen years old. On Tuesday, the 25th of February, I delivered a work-box belonging to my daughter, and various parcels, containing linen, books, and other things, to James Wood, in. Lothbury, to take to Plaistow—they were the property of my brother—I am not living with my husband, he is in Wales—this is the box and other articles which I deliver
ed to Wood (looking at them.)

JAMES WOOD . I am a labouring man. Mrs. Parker delivered the work-box and other things to me, to take to Plaistow, on a Tuesday night—I cannot tell the day of the month—I saw the prisoners on the road, conversing together—I drew my cart up by the side of the road, about ten minutes' walk from the Black Lion, and asked Walker to mind my cart, which he consented to do—he and Ruffett were both in company together then, but on my return from where I went, to inquire for the house, Ruffett had disappeared—Walker was still there—I had been gone about ten minutes—I gave Walker some halfpence for taking care of my cart—I know these articles were safe when I left the cart, for in getting out I put my hand upon the box, which I had particular directions not to

get wet or spoiled—I afterwards missed the box—I did not know what the handle contained—the things were taken out of it—I had other things in the cart—nothing was packed—they all laid loose in the body of the cart.

THOMAS BARTLETT (police-constable K 286.) On the 26th of February I was in Stratford, and saw the prisoners coming towards town—Ruffett had a bundle under his, arm, apparently in the shape of a box—I sus
pected and watched them—they went into Mr. Lamb's, in the Broad
way, Stratford, and came out in about a quarter of an hour, without the bundle—I immediately went up to them, and asked what they had done with the box they had had in their possession—they both said they had left it at Mr. Lamb's, who had advanced 1s. on it, and that they had found it in the New-road, going from Barking, a fortnight before—I asked if they had made inquiries about it—they said they had inquired all round Plaistow, and could find no owner for it—I took them back to Mr. Lamb's, found the box there, and took them into custody, on Walker was found a duplicate of some muslin and pillow-cases, pledged at Mr. Bressy's—I have not got the duplicate here, I gave it up after the second examination, but I have a receipt which they gave me for it—I got Walker to sign it.

Walker. We were out of the shop a quarter of an hour before we went back with you. Witness. It is false—I watched them out, and immedi
ately went and stopped them—I bad got about two hundred yards from Mr. Lamb's shop when I stopped them—I questioned them for about five minutes, and then took them back to Mr. Lamb's.

RICHARD LAMB . I am a jeweller at Stratford. The prisoners came to my house on Wednesday, February 26th, between one and two o'clock—they brought a work-box, and on asking them where they got it from, they said they found it on the New-road, leading to Barking, that a coach was on before, and they thought the box had dropped from that—I asked how long they had had it in their possession—they said nearly a fortnight—I asked if their friends knew they had found it—they said yes, and said they had been all over Plaistow to different parties to try to find out the owner for the box, but could not—I said I should not buy it of them, I thought I knew the party it belonged to—I said if they would call on Friday night, or the Saturday, after I had made necessary inquiries, I would tell them more on the subject—when they brought the box they wanted me to purchase it—I am sure they asked me to buy it—it was tied up with string, in brown paper, very carefully as if it was packed.

Walker. Q. Did we not ask you if you knew any owner for the box, when we came? A. I do not think you did—I did not state so at Lam
beth-street—they said they were cold and hungry—I gave them 1s., thinking if I could find the owner of the box, I should not be at the loss of the 1s.

CHARLES HENRY LAWKS . I am shopman to Mr. Bressy, pawnbroker of Stratford. I have four pieces of muslin, two pillow-cases, and a napkin, pawned by a boy, apparently seventeen or eighteen years old—on Wednes
day, the 26th of February, he asked me for 1s. 6d. on them—I lent him 6d.—I have no recollection of him—I firmly believe it to be Walker, but I will not be positive—Stratford is above a mile and a half or two miles from Plaistow—MR. Lamb's is about a mile and a quarter from Plaistow.
Walker's Defence. I did not take them from the cart; I had the cart in my charge.
Ruffett's Defence. I was not there.

WALKER*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years.

RUFFETT*—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1292.
HENRY HEIDEN was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Oliver Fain, on the 31st of March, and stealing therein, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; and 1 seal, value 6d.; the goods of
William Burgess.

WILLIAM BURGESS . I am foreman to Mr. Oliver Pain, of Broadway, Stratford, in the parish of West Ham. I had ft watch on the 31st of March, which I saw safe at eight o'clock at night, in the drawer in the bakehouse, which is part of the house—I came back at eleven o'clock—It was gone—I immediately informed the police, and told my suspicions—the prisoner was taken into custody on the following morning—this is my watch, chain, and seals—(looking at them)—the bakehouse-doors were shut when I left it—I shut them after me—when I returned, they were still shut—our people go in and out there.

FRANCIS HEAPHY . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into cus
tody, and told him Mr. Pain wanted to speak to him—he did not ask me what it was for, but accompanied me to Mr. Pain, who told him, in my presence, that a watch had been stolen out of the bakehouse, belonging to his man, and that he, the prisoner, was strongly suspected—he said the watch was stolen between nine and eleven o'clock—the prisoner re
marked, "I was in-doors at a quarter to ten o'clock"—there were foot-marks in the garden—he afterwards said that he went into the parlour, stole the watch, and put it into his boot—he pulled off his boot, and the pro
perty was found in it—he said he was sorry for it.
Prisoner. It is the first time I was in trouble; I throw myself on the mercy of the Court.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

p.rs: GUILTY of Larceny only. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy.

div1.p: Confined Three Months.

1293.
GEORGE HARVEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of April, 1 gelding, price 6l.; 1 set of harness, value 10s.; 1 cart, value 4l., and 3 pigs, value 3l. 19s.; the property of
John Regan.

JOHN REGAN . I live at East Ham, in Essex, and deal in pigs, which 1 take about in a cart. On Monday, the 6th of April, I met the pri
soner at the Duke's Head public-house, Walthamstow, about half-past twelve o'clock—he was generally about that house—I had three pigs in my cart, which had a pony to it, with harness on—I had to show some pigs to a lady, but I was taken very ill, and the prisoner said he would mind the cart, if I gave him a pint of beer—I asked him to take the horse and cart, and show the pigs to the lady—he was to have returned in a quarter of an hour, but I saw no more of him till he was in custody at Barnet—I never told him to sell the pigs, but to show them to the lady—the policeman afterwards showed me two of my pigs.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Suppose the lady took a fancy to them—the price of two was 28s., and the other, 24s.? A. Yes—he was to have a pint of beer when he returned.

CHARLOTTE WHITE . I live in Marsh-street, Walthamstow. About four o'clock on the 6th of April, the prisoner drove up to my door with a pony-cart and pigs—he asked if I wanted to buy a pig—I said I did—I went to the cart to look, and the one he put out he asked 25s. for—I gave him 23s.—I had seen him round with Regan's cart before—he said he was selling them for Regan, who was ill at the public-house.
Cross-examined. Q. Has Regan seen the one you bought? A. Yes.

ROBERT BURROWS . I bought a pig of the prisoner about half-past three o'clock—he had three at that time he asked me 30s. for it—I offered him 29s.—I gave him 15s. deposit—I asked where Regan was—he said he was ill at the public-house.

Cross-examined. Q. Where is the pig now? A. At my house—I told him he should have the remainder of my money to-day, and if Regan did not like it, he might come and take the pig back—he had part of file pots of beer at ray house—he was net drunk.

JAMES M'CULLOCH . I am a policeman—in consequence of information I followed the prisoner to Tottenham, and took him at Barnes, which is about twenty miles from Walthanstow—I found the horse and cart about three-quarters of a mile from where I found the prisoner—them was another man in his company who came from Wathamstow—they were both together waiting in a field where a booth was erecting for a fair—they appeared cooking a dinner—the last pig was sold there—the prisoner told me he had sold it for 18s.—I took him in charge and found a sovereign and a half in gold and four pence in silver on him—he said he had had a pleasant time of it and seemed to enjoy himself very well—he said he did not mind coming back as soon as he had his last dinner; that he had sold the last pig, and that was all the money he had.
Cross-examined. Q. He was going to return the horse and cart when he had dined? A. Yes—there was a dinner cooking, and, I believe, for him—he seemed half drunk.

JOHN HUNT . I am a policeman—I saw the prisoner in custody—he said, in going along, "If you had not come down we should have sold the horse and cart," meaning himself and the other man who was with him.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not the other man in the cart? A. Yes—he was not drunk—at the time he made use of this expression, we were on our road home to Walthamstow.

JOHN REGAN
re-examined. The pig he sold to Charlotte White was one I valued at 28s.—he would have to go past Burrows to go to the lady's—he was quite solid; if he had been drunk I would not have sent him—he was only to show the pigs to the lady—I told him the price, as he asked me what they were if she should ask him—he was not to sell them, only to see if they were the right size for the lady—she would not have bought of him—he was not trusted to sell them for me and receive the money—I would not have trusted him with the money—he was to bring the pigs back to me in a quarter of an hour, whether she liked them or not—I only mentioned the price as he asked me.

Cross-examined. Q. Suppose he had said the lady meant to keep two of them; would you not have been satisfied? A. I should have gone back to the lady to get the money—he was not to leave them—I did not send him to take the money—I nave never sent pigs by another person and received the money myself.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of stealing the Pigs only. Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1294.
SARAH BURKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of February, 2 combs, value 5d., the goods of
Daniel Donovan; and 1 purse, value 6d.; 12 yards of ribbon, value 2d.; and five yards of net, value, 1d.; the goods of
Henry Hunt, her master.

FRANCES SARAH DONOVAN . I am the wife of Daniel Donovan, and lodge with Mrs. Hunt, at East Ham—the prisoner came on the 28th of February, on liking, as a servant to Mrs. Hunt—she had no business in my apartments—on the 29th of February I lost two combs off my side-board—on the 6th of March my husband took her, and she gave these two combs out of her bosom—I have no doubt they are mine.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did she attend on you? A. No—I used to shut my door at night.

ANN HUNT . I am the wife of Henry Hunt—the prisoner was in my service for two days—I lost a purse, twelve yards of ribbon, and five yards of net out of a muff-box where I had put them on the 27th of February—the box was in a room which the prisoner had to scour—I did not know the prisoner before, but I had seen her pass, and being a strong girl I thought she might suit me.

DANIEL DONOVAN (police-constable K 319.) On the 29th of February my wife told me what she had lost, and on the 6th of March I saw the prisoner in East Ham, with my wife's side-combs in her hair—I took her to the station-house—in going along, she took the side combs from her hair and put them in her bosom—when we got there, I asked her for them—she said she had none, but took them out and gave them to me—on the next day I went with Mrs. Hunt to the prisoner's father, where I found this ribbon and net.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

1295.
THOMAS GARRETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of March, 1 pair of boots, value 1s., the goods of
James Thomas Humphries; to which he pleaded

GUILTY *. Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

1296.
SUSANNAH JANE CHEESEMAN was indicted
for a misde
meanor.

WILLIAM WATTS . I am a draper, and live in Broadway, Deptford. On the 7th of February, between six and eight o'clock, the prisoner came to my shop, and requested to take some shawls to show Mrs. Collins, of King-street, Deptford—I asked if she came from Mrs. Collins—she said, "Yes," and I gave her two shawls—I think the price was marked on them—on the following day I sent Arthur Osborne to Mrs. Collins, and on his return I gave information at the police station-house—MRS. Collins had been a customer of mine for some time—I had seen the prisoner at my shop once or twice before—I gave credit to her representation that she came from Mrs. Collins, and parted with them for no other purpose than for her to show Mrs. Collins.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you make a memorandum of the conversation between yourself and her? A. I did not—I believe her

words were, "I want to take some shawls to Mrs. Collins, in King-street, Deptford"—that is as near as I can recollect—I inquired what sort of shawls she wanted, and I believe she said they were to be good ones—the two were worth from 64s. to 65s.—I believe this to be one—(looking at one)—they were both very nearly alike—the ticket has been taken off—one was found on the prisoner, and the other at the pawnbroker's.

ELIZABETH COLLINS . I am the wife of John Collins, a traveller, and live at No. 5, King-street, Deptford. I have known the prisoner four years—I did not send her on any message on the 29th of November last—I know Mr. Watts—I did send her there for some linen on the 25th, which was the first time she came to work in my house—I had a child dying on the 29th—I did not send her for any thing on the 7th of February—I never saw her between November last and the 7th of February—she did not bring any shawls to me—I never authorised her in any way to apply for them.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A married woman I think—the prisoner was with me four days, from the 25th of November to the 29th—she came at ten o'clock in the morning, and left at night—she left earlier on the 29th, because my baby died that night—I did not see her again till I saw her before the Magistrate at Greenwich, when the duplicate of my watch, chain, and seals, was found on her—I was never before a Magistrate in my life—I keep a lodging-house.

Q. Is it a house of such description that young men and women come without your knowledge and sleep there? A. A gentleman may come—I do not allow strangers to sleep there—I consider it a proper moral house—I do not consider it an immoral house, unless I am taken before a Magistrate—I was brought here to prosecute the prisoner last Sessions, and gave evidence against her—perhaps I might have said on that occasion that I did not consider mine a proper moral house—I have come to state the truth—I may very likely let lodgings in this way when my husband is at home—I did not say last time that I had eleven children—I said I was the mother of eleven—I have eight now—I married a gentleman, but misfortunes may overtake you as well as me—the prisoner is a straw-bonnet and dress-maker—I knew she was a gay and unfortunate girl—she was frequently at my house, because her mother was committed to Maidstone gaol for starving a child to death, and she had nowhere to go—that was not the reason why I let her live in my house, but she had nobody to take care of her at home—I swore to the property at the last trial, and here is part of it round my neck now—I was shamefully treated last trial—I had not a vestige in me, I had not a feeling about me but what was numbed.

Q. You did not get the watch, did you? A. Oh, but she got it—I could bring forward the man that put my initials on it—I got the chain, and she got the watch—I take in married women and their husbands, and perhaps single girls and their husbands.

RICHARD PARRY . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Flagon-row, Dept
ford. I produce a scarf which I took in of the prisoner, on the 7th of February, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, in the name of Jane Cheeseman—I knew her before—I lent her 14s. on it—I asked her if it was her own property, and she said, "Yes."
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Mrs. Collins? A. I never saw her till she was at the office.
BENJAMIN LOVELL . (police-constable K 15.) On the 8th of February I received information, in consequence of which I apprehended the prisoner,

on the 12th or 13th of February, in High-street, Woolwich, three or four miles from High-street, Deptford—I met her with another female, named Thurley—I told her I wanted her—she asked what for—she had this shawl on—MR. Watts, who was with me, laid hold of the shawl, and said, "That is one of my shawls"—I told her she had better come to Mrs. Thurley's house—we went there, and I said she must go to the station-house—she said, "Mr. Watts, I hope you will forgive me; I know I have done wrong; I intended to pay you, and will pay you now"—I asked if she had any du
plicate—she said, "No"—MRS.
